Taste is also complex, rich toffee caramel with dried fruits, sultanas and raisins. Big thick and sweet. Very tasty

75cl bottle at Appellation Wines. Pours beautiful dark amber with a nice head. The nose has a lot of sweetness and maybe fruits.The taste has of some bitter orange, a lot of sweetness. Medium to full bodied and a long staying finish. Alcohol might be a bit too dominant, but otherwise very nice beer.
@ Basunen: En riktig söt maltdoft. Lätt maltig smak, söt och ganska balanserad. Fruktig eftersmak. lagom het.

Bottle from Systembolaget.

Amber with a medium white head. Sweet aroma and taste. Toffee, dried fruit, malt and some alcohol. A very nice beer to sip, also a very nice balance on this one. I need another bottle.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2013 First rating75 cl bottle thanks to Johan (not on ratebeer). BB 2017-12-31, sampled on September 22, 2012As of ratebeer instructions its the 2003 vintage we just had. As of Johan the bottle is bought recently from Systembolaget.Clear dark copper color, tan head. Sweet, caramel. alcohol, malty, hoppy, dark fruits scent. Malty, bitter, caramel, sweet, fruity, some mint taste. Warming alcohol. Medium big, smooth mouthfeel. Big/high bitterness.9/4/9/4/18=4.4RerateBottle at NK Bar, Stockholm, on December 9, 2013.75 cl bottle.Hazy copper color, small light brown head. Sweet, malty, herbal, light bit roasted scent. Malty, caramel, citrus taste. Warming alcohol. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.9/3/9/4/18=4.3

Pours copper with high frothy head. Great start!
Aromas of barley, brown sugar, raisins, hints of citrus, flowery
Warm barley wine style sweetness. Great neatness, very well balanced, sits perfect... Great barley from alesmith!

Bomber tnx to Niklas. Pours clear redish dark amber with a nice bubbly beige head leaving lace. Aroma is malty sweet raisins alcohol fruity. Flavor is bitter fruity malty raisins fidges sweet a. It astringent pungent alcohol. Finishes bitter malty alcohol and sweet.

Bottle,  
this ale poured a clear red-brown with bronze like colors at the sides of the glass and gave a three finger off-white/light tan head of bubbles, the beer left a lot of sticky, foamy layer of bubbles and spots on the glass, the effervescence appeared to be less than medium but the beer did not feel watery or flat on the tongue, there was some dark sediment on the bottom of the bottle (not a cover but a partial thick ring of sediment),   

there were aromas of yeast that reminded me of their IPA, hops that reminded me of their IPA with the amount of hop resins on the nose, some hop citrus, some alcohol esters of fruit, fruit citrus, caramel, malty, smells like it had a lot of hops, 

lots of malt flavor with fruit, some lemon and grapefruit citrus spikes, and some caramel, light toasted malt, 
there was a lot of hop bitterness in this drink, I think I should have aged the bottle a while, 
the taste reminded me of a IPA that had sat around a while, this ale still needs to sit a while longer to calm down a bit, there was lots of candy and sugar sweetness, hops oils and herby green notes that linger on the palate after the drink, 

the mouth feel is more than medium and less than full, not as full as I expected for a Barley Wine drink, 
there was a hint of alcohol on the palate, just a small hint of alcohol warmth, 

this drink reminded me of a IPA or IPA2 that had sat around a bit, there was more hops than expected, the hop nose has calmed down a bit but the bitterness is still there, the alcohol was hidden somewhat well.

Bottle 7 Beer tasting club - Poured with a great level of viscosity expected from a barley wine with a red hue.
Malty with a huge hop notes quite fruity almost like a really fruity sticky Christmas cake in a liquid form.

750ml bottle. Wonderful clear reddish amber copper colour with average, lasting, frothy to creamy, lacing, tan head. Aroma is a conglomeration of hop and malt notes, caramel, toffee, bitter hoppy counterweight. Taste is similar in structure, very close mixture of malt and hop notes, very clean and pure.

Deep brown-amber body, moderate sized pale brown head, bubbly foam, a few stray streaks of lacing.  Nose is pure malt with a healthy dose of caramel, toffee, a little chocolate, and a strong undercurrent of booze.  Flavor is similar with a leathery, caramel sweetness dominating.  Medium to full bodied, a bit hot, light bitterness, moderate carbonation.

Pours a wonderful, clear and deep copper with a medium, thick off-white head. Aroma is towards the malty side, with bread, earth, caramel malt. Theres a hint of fruity hops, but the malt clearly dominates. Taste is thick and sweet, with a long and lingering sweetish finish with just a hint of hoppy bitterness in the backbone. Body is full and creamy with low carbonation. A very nice, well balanced barley wine, although I would have wanted it to be a bit more extreme in some way, its a touch too polite for my liking...

pours a semi-cloudy ruby hue with a large ten head, and great lacing.

smell is of grain, some caramel, bark, hops, and some citrus.

taste is chewy and smooth, grain, malt, some hops, caramel, and a little citrus.  ends dry and smooth.
Hazy, dark amber with white head. Aroma of roasted malt, hops and fruits. Flavour is hoppy, bitter and sweet. Pretty simple but still rather good.

Very fruity...pineapple aroma. Smells full bodied and very sweet. Yhr color is an amber red color and hazy with an off white head. The taste is sweet on my tounge and no alcohol taste like many barley wines. It seems kind of bland after the initial taste. Theres no bitterness which is normal and theres no other flavors. Its just sweet the palate was a medium bodied...overall not horrible but maybe worth a taste.

Pours nice copper color with a thick off white head and good lace. Aroma is malts, caramel, fruits, alcohol as it warms. Taste is malty, some sweetness, caramel, whiskey type flavor comes through as well, dry palate with a long dry malty, warming finish. Excellent!

Cloudy red-orange with a ton of floaters and carbonation; murky. Decent, creamy head that sticks around and lingers on the inside of the glass.

First whiff: rubber. Hmm. Grainy cereal malts, followed by a flowery hop. Not as alcohol-heavy or cloying as some barleywines. Color me intrigued.

Really interesting flavor: major raisin, like an actual cardboard box of raisins. Overwhelming really. There is a liqueur flavor attached to it, like grenadine or something. Touch of cherry.

Feels chunky, appropriate for style. Its a very raisin-y barleywine. Seriously, its like liquid raisins.

Apariencia: color rojo anaranjado, nada turbio, muy bonito, recuerda un poco al brandy, poco carbónico, corona escasa de color beige, desaparece rápido. Puntito alcohólico. 
Aroma: muy intenso, complejísimo, domina el lúpulo: resina, pino y cítricos, después pasa a dominar la malta, vainilla y caramelo, con el paso del tiempo, el lúpulo apenas se percibe ya. 
Sabor: mucho cuerpo, muy complejo, predomina absolutamente la malta, caramelo, vainilla, especias, frutos secos, nueces, algo de humo, pasas... Alcohol mejor integrado que en la nariz. 
espectacular, una cerveza complejísima, pero bastante equilibrada, muchísimos matices y cambia mucho a lo largo de la sesión.
Bottled sample from Phoenix.  Caramel colour.  Great wine flavour.  Went great with Apple Pie

Bottle (750 ml). Huge thanks to pushkinwow for this one! Light brown with a small off-white head and amazing lacing. Aroma of pine, caramel, citrus and malt. Taste is more of caramel, with malt, pine, vanilla and citrus notes. Slight bitterness. Mouthfeel is oily. Very good barleywine. Drinkable for the style. Not very complex but really well balanced.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours dark mahogany with high creamy beige head. Intense lacing. Aroma is of malt, citrus, caramel, pine. Taste is of malt, caramel, citrus, pine. Overall: full bodied. Very good balance. Bitter finish. Alcohol well-hidden.
Very malty caramel flavor.  Large lingering tan head.  Sweet fruit taste.  Long finish with fruit and hoppiness.  Very well done and doesnt Ferrell like such a strong beer

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2012 75cl bottle. Pours a beautiful copper with a beautifully proportioned head. The nose has cake mixture and a touch of ginger. The taste is of burnt oranges, ginger biscuits and zingy marmalade finish on the end. The palate is medium to full bodied with a tangy middle texture and a long persistent finish. There is a little too much alcohol for my Overall, a great beer.

750ml. bottle, thanks Poisoneddwarf-  Pours a nice hazy dark orange with a nice creamy off white head and execllent lacework. Aroma is strong malt, basically like a typical barleywine, but it has a nice sweet candy like malt too. The taste is pretty mellow for a barleywine, with still that huge malt presence. It almosts has a barrel aged taste to it, and candy like sweetness again. Body is massive, carbonation is medium. Overall I thought it was a world class barleywine, but this is just not my favorite style.

750 ml bottle shared with brenn79. Pours hazy amber with a thick beige head with excellent retention; lace sheets the glass. Beautiful. Aroma is extremely malty--caramel, molasses, raisins, soy sauce. Taste is malty sweet with a bit of bitterness in the finish. Hot alcohol presence in the finish, too. Body is full. Im not as big on barleywines as I used to be, but this is a complex, expertly made brew. If I had rated this a couple years ago, I wouldve given it a higher score.

Bottle at home. Poured into a snifter a deep crimson in appearance, with a frothy tan head and great lacing. Aroma is very citrusy upfront with hints, of figs, vanilla, toffee, and sweet honey on the back-end. As it begins to warm the smell is much sweeter and the hop profile is subdued, but it still smells wonderful. Raisins, plum, candi sugar, light roast, grapefruit, a touch of vanilla, and some cognac flavors in the taste, ending moderately bitter with resinous aftertastes. Creamy/sticky mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Beautifully well-balanced; sweet, yet bitter, creamy and complex. A real treat to drink. I will thoroughly enjoy this entire bottle all by myself. Cheers!

Bottle.  Pours dark reddish-brown with a large off-white head.  Amazing aroma of caramel, toffee, bready malts, fresh fruits and pine.  Flavor is a great balance of hops and heavy malts.  Notes of fresh fruit, sweet caramel, dried fruits, piney hops, toffee and a touch of wood.  Moderately sweet caramel finish with a touch of alcohol.  Great barleywine.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2012 Pours a clear dark amber color with a nice head that lingers a bit. Big aroma of caramel malt, flowers, toffee, and honey. Wow nice flavor. Tons of caramel malt balanced with smooth floral and earthy hops. Strong bitterness cuts through the sweet malt. Finish is long and bitter leaving a floral and caramel taste for a while.  One of my favorite barleywines. Perfectly balanced.  12/23/12 re-rate:  Had this again and I just love it.  Even better than I remember.

Pours a nice orange with an off white head. Just a little hazy. Aroma is quite complex. Caramel leads the the list of citrus, figs, brown sugar, and bright fruits. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Caramel and toffee flavors are balanced by alcohol and a light bitterness. Fresh pears and burnt sugar round out the finish.

Pours light orange with notes of carmalized fig and slight alcohol.   Deep and complex mouthfeel that limits the stickiness but shows dense toffee, burnt orange, and dried pears.   Nice moderate finish.
Taken from old notes. Boozy, caramel and hoppy nose-straight up barley wine. Taste is hoppy up front with a caramel malt backbone. Alcohol is present on taste and finish. Well blended.

Old Numbskull has a very clear, light brown appearance. There is a moderate amount of head and lacing. Sweet malts with hints of caramels, toffee, and alcohol are the basic make up of the scents and tastes. Alcohol is pretty evident throughout the smell, taste, and finish of the beer. The feel is decent, with a prominent butterscotch candy note in the back, which I find to be rather enjoyable.
75cl, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, very complex bitter brew, alcoholic/bitter and slightly fruity/woody, very heavy, yet balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew, yet expensive!
Bomber. Rich murky copper pour with a monster head. Fruity and caramel aroma. Smooth palate. Taste is rich caramel, pine, and light fruit. Solid.

Draught at the brewery. Almost clear, deep amber/brown liquid with medium light tan head. Aroma of sweet caramel, grassy and citrusy hops, biscuit and blackberries. Taste is light to medium sweet and miedum bitter with notes of caramel and citrus. Full bodied with medium carbonation.

Bottle shared at tasting.  Pours clear amber with a small tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, toffee, resinous hops and light grapefruit.  Flavour is light heavy sweet with moderate bitterness head behind.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.

66cl bottle shared.
Thin white head.
Clear amber pour.  Sweet hoppy aftertaste, more hoppy.  Lovely beer!

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2012 Ar: Very strong - hops and malt, carmel and dried fruits.
Ap: Deep, dark amber with a frothy, creamy head that diminishes into a light cloud fluff
T: Malty, hoppy - more sweet than bitter, well balanced and lingers well for quite a while
P: Full bodied, soft carbonation
O: Great marriage of all aspects.  One of the best non-bourbon aged barley wines Ive had because of its incredible balance.

On bottle at Olympen, Oslo.
Dark reddish color, good foam.
Aromas; some immediate peat, lots of malty dried fruit aromas & some hops.medium/ low carbonation, high viscosity. 
Full body & high complexity
sweet, but balanced with bitterness.
Very enjoyable

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottled. Pours a deep brown with fantastic beige head. Malts and deep fruits aroma but not too overpowering given the inherent power.  A great beer.

Could quite possibly be one of the top 100 beers/Barleywines in the world.  The aroma is inviting, but not overwhelming  Pours a murky copper with a dense,  2 finger, amber head.   Would rate a 5 if it werent for the slightly oily mouth-feel at the finish.
Pours amber with a low head. Aroma is sweet malts and alcohol. Flavor is malts, caramel, alcohol and plenty of hops. Interesting barley wine. Excellent.
Bottle. Pours murky brown with rich tan head. Aroma of sugary malt, alcohol with a bit of spice. Flavor is the same and sweet. Heavy mouthfeel with low-medium carbonation. Great brew!!!
A must try barely wine. It has a descent scent. The taste isnt overwhelming & it wont mess up youre palate. I would have another.

Pours a light brown with reddish tint, and a big thick lasting head with good lacing. Aroma is sweet malt with hints of apricot and peaches. Taste is balance of malt, hops and alcohol. This tastes surprising hot with alcohol. Not really sweet for this style. Surprisingly, not very complex, and alcohol is one of the main contenders in the palate, followed by hop bitterness. This is not enjoyable to me. Too hot and too simple.

Is this beer suppose to be flat? Beer is brown and hazy with nearly no head, no carbonation, no lacing. Oh no!

Aroma of the beer is unimpressive, mildly sweet, some fruitiness, overall VERY WEAK.

Beer begins looking up in flavor, seriously. About damn time. Beer is medium in body, thick on the palate, Mildly bitter at the end but entirely from grains, a late residual sweetness, not my favorite but a decent beer overall. Sucks Im ending my night with such an unremarkable beer.

Serving type: bottle

0.75 l bottle at Vihreä Haltiatar, Jyväskylä. Amber color. Sweet floral and citrusy flavor with nutty maltiness and perfumed alcohol. Bittersweet, nutty, floral and lemony flavor with soft warming alcohol. Full bodied but not heavy. Very tasty and fairly drinkable too. Not in your face barley wine, more like a delicate and sophisticated.

Flaske: Ravfarvet klar øl med et stort skumhoved. Duften er fantastisk. Masser af amerikansk humle, citrus og en smule fyr ovenpå en kæmpe maltbase med en smule tørret frugt. Virkelig lækker. Smagen sidder også i skabet. Klassisk amerikansk BW med masser af humle uden at ryge over i en DIPA. Fantastisk drikbar øl.

Bottle @ beer temple. 
Pour deep ruby-red, with a small tan head. 
Aroma has plenty of caramel, vanilla, american hops - pine, some tropical fruits, slight ripe fruits as well. A little strange to me, with the big malt backbone, and all the hops as well. Works fine though. 
Taste is sweet up front, with a hoppy bitter aftertaste. Medium body, with a semi-flat carb.
A lovely but fairly straightforward barleywine. Lots of caramel malt, hoppy finish, a bit of alcohol warming--almost a bourbon quality. Good, but lacking  a bit of complexity for this much flavor.

Bottled. Pours a clear amber to brown with a small beige head. Nose of dark, riped fruit and alcohol notes. Sweet flavor with riped fruits, caramel and brown sugar. Full bodied, oily to syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Ends up more dry with warming alcohol. Anothr world class beer from Alesmith.
Pours ruby red with moderate white head and sticky lacing. Nose is deep malt and sweet hops. Taste is complex toffee malt with a nice hop bite and a sweet alcohol burn. Pretty tasty.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2013 (Bottle, 0.75 l, at Gallows Bird, 20120523) The beer poured mahogany coloured and clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had malts, hops and sweetness. Palate was full bodied and warming with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, fruitiness, tangerine, hops, mild sweetness and medium bitterness. Aftertaste was malty, hoppy and bitter. Low sweetness was really nice as were the fruity hops. Bit harsh. Old rating: B-4-8-2-15.

(Re-rate, bottle from Alko Arkadia, 20130426) Palate was better. Perhaps this bottle was a little bit older. Alcohol was well hidden and the sweetness had dimished.

75 cl bottle thanks to Rasmusott. The last beer at the tasting on 5/5/12, and Im transcribing directly, and take notice of the regularity of the word "stuff". Hazy amber red pour, nice consistent off white head. Aroma has buckets of American hops, citrusy and piney - but aged! Nice caramel and raisins, lovely malt profile, sherry, tiramisu, a hint of ripe pineapple. The taste is just what an American barley wine should be - love malt profile - caramel, raisins, lovely malty stuff and a good deal of hoppiness - citrusy and piney (centennial and stuff) - lovely stuff!

Shared 750 ml bottle @ Cosmic Comic Cafe.  Pours a a deep, dark, reddish amber with a medium, yellowish-brown head that leaves quite a nice lacing. Aroma is quite sweet with caramel, resin, molasses, some pith and pine, a hint of ethanol and dried fruit as well. Taste begins stingy pith and caramel with caramel and resin taking more space in the middle, grapefruit on the finish with some dried, dark fruits as well. Quite sweet though not too much. Palate is full, quite oily, a bit sticky.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2012 Pours unclean deep reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is nice fruity hops, peach, plums, pine, darker malts, caramel, thick orange, weak resin and overall pretty american barley winish. Taste is ripe fruits, hops, pine, dryish bitterness, syrup, caramel, peach, thick orange and an overall fresh feeling to it! Drinkability is top notch!

Bottle from secret santa, pours a deep ruby/brown with a large khaki head. Aroma is doughy, figs, caramel, honey. Taste similar to aroma but sharp, with toffee and bitter hops on the finish. Very nice!

Pours cloudy golden brown color with an off-white head. Caramel and hoppy aroma. Flavor is smooth and dense hoppy and medium sweet caramel malty flavour. Fruity hops and mild spiced finish. Good stuff!

Reddish brown appearance with a big, tan head. Very nice, floral hoppy, toasty toffee, fairly sweet caramel malty aroma. Somewhat floral hoppy bitter, sweet, toffee, dark sweet flavor. Balanced and very nice.
Pours a reddish brown color with a tan head. Aroma apples, grapefruit and caramel malts. Taste is sweet with dark fruits and caramel/toffee. Very low carbonation and smooth. Medium to full mouthfeel.

Poured from the bottle. Poured light, with a nice white head, and thick lacing. Aroma is dark fruit, some ethanol. Flavor also has the dark fruity flavors, some heat with the alcohol. The beer is thick and oily.. Doesnt finish as dry as I would expect, leaves some sweetness. But it is good. I do notice some bitterness from the hops. I am thinking citrusy hops.
Bottle @ home. Aroma is very rich malt, big hops and caramel. Flavour is sweet and malty, caramel, hops, spice. Awesome. Lazy rate great beer.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2012 Brown with a red glow. Minimal head. Nuts, dried figs, dried hops, dry fruit. Taste is much better. Some sharp bitterness, but mostly a rich and flavourful ale. Not as concentrated maybe, but a great flavour. (75cl bottle, at dEnk house tasting)

Bottle at mini-dEnk tasting. Clear deep amber pour, thin white head. Aroma is spicy, alcoholic and fruity. Flavor is spicy, bitter, full bodied and a bit alcoholic. Very fruity and well balanced. A bit alcoholic.
Bottle with Nate. Dark amber, off white head. Dark sugar, dried fruits (raisins), caramel, cherry, toffee, spices.
Bottle pours pretty dark head fades fairly fast smells of dark fruits hops caramel. Not bad bit hop heavy would like it to be there more at end.
Pours a dark amber color. Nose is dark fruit, cherry, crystal malt and floral hops. Taste is sweet caramel malt, chocolate and vanilla, followed by a hoppy finish . Medium mouthfeel.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2014 La première chose qui me vient en tête...Sucre à la crème sur le coin de la table au jour de lan. Fantastique assaut du malt avec un apport résineux des houblons tellement parfait. La scène appartient à la caramélisation...Impitoyable!

Bottle. 2007 vintage. Poured a clear ruby-orange color. The head was a few fingers high. It dissipated relatively quickly to a thin lasting film. Orange zest, toffee, brown sugar, cherry, dark fruit, and baking spice aromas. Fruit cake-like, actually. Medium bodied and moderately sweet with a mild warming alcohol effect. Rum-raisin, brown sugar, toffee, and subdued cinnamon flavors. Still tasty five years on.

Bottle shared at Pizza Port Bottle Shop. It pours hazy brown-amber, with a thin beige head. The nose is tinned fruit - peach, nectarine and pear, as well as apple, caramel and buttered toast. The taste is raisin, fig, currant, booze, caramel, brown sugar, honey and some bitterness, with brown sugar in the finish. Full body and fine carbonation. A solid barley wine, if a touch too sweet.
Beautiful dark amber color.  Nose is dark fruit/prune.  Raisins up front, finish with alcohol and bitter hops.  Nice example of barleywine.  Early bottles or on tap probably get a lot more hop aroma

Bottle @ Aarons place, Thanks. Pours hazy dark brown with a small offwhite head. Aroma of malt, caramel, oak, vanilla, light fruit, grapefruit, hops. Taste is malty, caramel, wood, oak, vanilla, fruity, grapefruity hops. 
Medium body, soft carbonation. Hoppy but very well balanced barley wine, great stuff. 020312

Bottle @ home. Reddish brown appearance with a big, tan head. Very nice, floral hoppy, toasty toffee, fairly sweet caramel malty aroma. Somewhat floral hoppy bitter, sweet, toffee, dark sweet flavor. Balanced and very nice.

Pour was  deep dark amber, with some sweet molasses malts, and citrusy hop aromas. The taste was complex- defined brown sugars, ripe cherries round out the sweetness while the resinous hops hit the tongue with a grapefruit hop-bomb. The sweet burning from the alcohol is evident but not distracting whatsoever. The finish is dry and despite the oily hop flavor, stays that way. Great hop flavors and the brew is light even though the flavors are so thick. Great Barley Wine.

27/07/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (750ml vintage bottle). Ambrato carico, con riflessi rubino, lieve cappello di schiuma morbidissima, bianco sporca, poco persistente. Aroma intensissimo di malto, caramello, frutta, luppolo. In bocca è veramente una pigna, struttura di malto e luppolo a volontà sul finale, molto, molto lungo, quasi un amaro da fine pasto. Corpo pieno, carbonazione corretta. Forse un filo troppo luppolato e mappazza.
Sampled in the big bottle. Aged for 2 plus years. Poured with a big head on it and a sweet aroma. Has a big time malty flavor that really powers through and gives the beer a big flavor pop.

750 ml bottle shared by Lynux- thanks again, Sean! 2009 vintage. Pours a clear, bright amber color with a small eggshell white ring. Aroma of caramel and toasted malts, toffee, dried fruits, brown sugar, molasses, and earth. Flavor of sweet, toasted, and caramel malts, raisins, dates, toffee, and some bitter earthiness. Medium-full bodied, with moderate carbonation and a chewy, sweet mouthfeel. Dry finish. Just a big, good American barleywine.

Snifter pour. Aromas consist mainly of cherries and dark caramel. Slight alcoholic notes, but not much. Some slight citrus from the hops, as well. Poured a golden amber color with a touch of haze and a very foamy head. Small bubbles. Taste was similar with malts that give off flavors of red fruits and luscious caramel. There was even a light grainy aftertaste. The alcohol disappeared in the flavor. Extremely well hidden. This is a very easy drinking barley wine. Another excellent brew from Alesmith.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 What a catch this one was. This gem of a brew poured nice and golden with a fluffy ol head. Aromas were mainly boozy and cherry with only a hint of roasted caramel. The taste was bright and complex like most barley wines, but had much more hops than others, and the alcohol was very well hidden. 11% percent!? Great!!!!!!! A great big thanks to OmegaX for sharing!

The barley wine Ive had, and its one of my favorite styles, so Ive had many.  The hop notes are beautiful with the decadence of the malt.  Slight fruitiness in the aroma with that strong alcohol burn.  Love this beer!

Pours a dark reddish amber with huge creamy off white head.  Aroma is very malty with rich caramel, honey, and some notes of piney, citrus hops.  Taste is delicious with lots of rich sweet malt and the perfect amount of hop bitterness to bring balance to the palate.  Very well executed barley wine.

2002 bottle.  I received it as a wedding gift from my brother.  Pours a nice ruby red with a bright white head which quickly fades from the top.  Strong notes of malt and carmel, as well as rasin skins.  Sweet attack which fades to a warm and sweet, mellow, malty finish.  A wonderful, wonderful brew.

Brown, tan head, significant cloudy yeast sediment at bottom (nice).  Aroma is caramel and resinous, floral hops.  Flavor is straightforward, caramel obscuring the details of the hops.  Medium, clean bitterness.  Medium-heavy body.  Drinkable.  slight appricot, hint of bubblegum (just a hint).  Not as complex/interesting as I was expecting.

Aroma of toffee/ caramel/ malts/ brown sugar. Appearnce is reddish brown with thin head. taste is sweet with a hint of hop on the back end but little bitterness. Palate is a bit thin, wanted more oily, viscosity. Overall this is a really nice barleywine that would really warm the guts on a cold day.

Rating #600. 2010 vintage. 750 mL bottle from Total Wine in Tucson, served in a snifter. Pours hazy reddish chestnut with a small tan head that fades to a thin remnant, leaving a trace amount of fine lace. The nose has big notes of caramel, molasses and toasted malts, along with alcohol, figs, raisins, herbs and a touch of earth. The flavour is moderately sweet with molasses, caramel, figs and raisins, with a balancing slight bitterness. Slightly bitter notes of cocoa and herbs emerge towards the end and endure through the finish, which is long, peppery and slightly bitter. On the palate, it is full in body with a dryish texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent barley wine. It has beautifully complex malts with nice cocoa, hops and spice for balance. Very tasty. I would love to compare this one to a young example. 2011-12-25

On tap at Alesmith tasting room.  Pours a caramel color with some foamy beige head.  Nose has some citrus hops and alcohol.  Taste is slightly sweet with a fair amount of bittering hops in the back end.  I get a bit of caramel or toffee in this.  Nice.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2012 A -pours dark red brown hazy no head no lacing. 

S - dark dried fruits, prunes, dates, raisins, subtle chocolate malts abd light floral hops, some piny notes. 

M- heavy syrupy body with no car and some lacing. 

T - dried dark fruits on the nose. raisin first. Prunes dates and dried apricots. Light floral spicy hops. Malty sweet ale ending. Nice warm booze throughout, but not over powering. Very fruity barley wine, with a nice hoppy middle, and a lingering malty end.

7+

750 mL bottle.  Pours a reddish amber with a large off-white head.  Caramelly, toasty aroma, with some hints of pine and dark fruit, a little suggestion of alcohol.  Flavor leads with bitter pine resin hoppiness, blending into caramel and toasted biscuit.  An extremely well-made barley wine.

Bouteille de 750ml. Encore une fois merci SlovakSniper. Barley wine orangé avec une mousse brune. Le nez est exubérant, fruité, avec du caramel, une tonne de malt et du houblon. La bouche est décadente avec des goûts de caramel, de malt. de la tire Sainte-Catherine (Klendack !!). La texture est ronde, gluante, épaisse et visqueuse. Une bière à boire à petite gorgée.

(Thanks to JB84 for this world class barley wine)  Une superbe tête mousseuse beige repose sur un liquide aux contours profondément ambrés.  Des parfums qui transpirent les houblons fruités et lexotisme avec une base richement maltée et indéniablement décadente.  Une présence dalcool et des fruits foncés qui chatouillent les narines.  Un nez fabuleux qui frise la perfection.  Des saveurs qui sont caramélisées avec des malts grillés et des houblons savoureux, justement amérisants, remplis de fruits tropicaux et de résine.  Une réelle virtuosité.  Une bouche pleine et habitée, un corps solide, un pétillement maîtrisé et une texture plantureuse.  Une finale complexe et chaude, une rencontre du meilleur des deux mondes, un cadeau pour les papilles.

Pour is a nice mahogany with a thin tan head. Nose is of dark fruits, and brown sugar. Taste is of several different dark fruits, such as dates and plums with a plain brown sugar taste. Palate is shocking smooth considering.
Deep coppery red in color with a foamy tan head. Very strong but smooth. Malty with a punchy finish. Flavors include fig, cherry, raisin. Deep and complex.

Bottled. Good-looking deep amber beer with creamy and lacy head. Freshly hopped nose has citrusy, polleny and resiny notes with loads of dried fruits (pineapple, raisins) and some ripe berries. A hint of alcohol. Sturdy, slightly toasted/bready maltiness, some bittersweet caramel and a hint of nuts in the finish. Bitter taste, sweetness is more fruity than caramelly, a touch of alcohol. Lingerin, resiny bitter finish with warming alcohol. Full bodied, velvety texture with supersmooth carbonation. Very nice barley wine.

Very good barleywine, and rating #500!

Pours dark brown with no head, very little carbonation.  Tastes better as it gets warmer, if I had another one I would serve at room termperature.  Theres a slight bit of hops at the front of the palate, but they go quickly.  Its then smooth and sweet and very much dark dried fruit.  Finish lasts but doesnt overpower.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours clear orange/red with a creamy head. Aroma of caramel malts, dark fruits, butterscotch. Flavour the same, but with some woody notes in there too, and quite hoppy for this style. I like how the hops make the finish lighter rather than being another heavy barley wine. Smooth, rich and full bodied

Bottle. Thinner bubbly light tan head with spidery lacing; murky orange brown hue. Pruney, rich, malty, earthy, toffee, and dark fruit sweetness.  Very sweet with some oxidation notes which was sad, but very much is malty and sweet, dark fruits.  Medium body with bubbly carbonation.  Need to try fresher sample

Denmark, Aug-Sept 2009. Bottle from fonefan. Clear red amber, with a tiny head. VEry intense aromatic hop aroma with caramel notes. Smooth taste for a BW that strong, good balance between the  caramel malts and teh aroamtic hops. I really like good american Barley wines and this is no exception.

2007 bottle: Walnut, wood, and caramel nose. Dingy brown, thin yellow head. Wood and marizipan flavor. Full body. Little hop presence, not too hot. I prefer a hoppier barleywine and this may have been at one time, but with this much age, it doesnt do as much for me.

Barleywine beer isnt quite my favorite style of beer.  But a chilly November day is the perfect time for one.  One a side note, Ive been itching for some AleSmith beers lately.  So when I visited my local beer store to pick up a case of something different, I found a bottle of Old Numbskull.  The way the world works is sometimes a mystery, but it worked perfectly today!  AleSmiths Old Numbskull is an absoute work of art and genious!  The beer pours a semi-cloudy ruby red with a small, but patterned, cascading and beautifully laced, off-white head.  The aroma is perfect!  Its so inviting and eleqouent, with notes of floral hops, caramel, toasted malt, nuts, rye bread, candi sugar, bourbon, sweet alcohol and a touch of honey.  The body is so well-balanced!  This is a very dangerous beer!  It has the flavor and drinkablility that you could take one sip after another all evening.  But after just one 750ml bottle, youre gonna feel it!  The flavors are extremely delicious, well-balanced and so enjoyable!  The beer gets even better after warming a bit, too!  I taste caramel malt, floral and semi-spicy hops, earth, rye bread, a little bit of black pepper, honey, grass, bourbon, dark red grapes and yeast.  The finish is a little dry, but balanced and superb.  The aftertaste is one of the more engaging parts, as it keeps you coming back to the glass for sip after sip after sip.  I also get that warming feeling of alcohol and love.  Old Numbskull is an absoute beast; strong, wonderful, balanced and delicously awesome!

Pour copper amber with a light beige head good lace. Aroma citrus, pine, caramel, resiny hops, toffee, sweet malt, dark fruit, candy sugar. Taste caramel, citrus, pine. maple, toffee, resiny hops, dark fruits. MF medium to full body nice carb. Overall excellent taste really well balanced and one of the tastiest brews Ive had in a while.

Appearance: deep brilliantly clear mahogany and cherry woods under a khaki tannish head. A slow stream of bubbles keeps the head intact while releasing a tantalizing nose. Swirls with a thin yet full layer of lace.

Nose: hoppy, dry, rustic, chocolate, plums. Plum and grape skins. Fall leaves, dry wood and sticks. Whole hop cones with an evergreen essence. Red apple skins. Luxurious and silky.

Palate: lovely marriage of chocolate and plums followed by sticks, twigs, and whole dried hop cones. Plums and grapes start sweet with their juicy innards and end with the thirst-inducing bitter tannic tang of their skins. Twigs and fall leaves mingle with an air of seasons. Black cherries and chocolate bark. Clean mouthfeel, medium-bodied, and silky. Rustic finish with pits and stems. Lovely.

Final Thoughts: AleSmith belongs in Floridaokay, I want AleSmith in Florida but thats kind of the same thing. The sunshine state aside, no matter where you are, if you stumble across some AleSmith beers, buy and/or drink as much as you can because they really are that good. A phenomenal Barleywine Id gladly drink over and over again.

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Sampled from a 750 ml brown bottle this beer poured a dark caramel-brown color with a large creamy orange-tan head that lingered forever and left good lacing. The aroma was sweet molasses, raisin, plum and caramel. The flavor was sweet raisin and plum with moderate caramel and molasses and a bit of alcohol coming through. The finish was very long with lingering raisin, plum and molasses. Thick and syrupy body. Excellent.
Pours a medium brown with slight red hew. Nose is vanilla and a malty cider like quality. Finish is pleasant. Very drinkable for barley wine.

(750 ml bottle from cloudskipper, sampled 6/17/11). Clear amber color. medium off white head. Moderate sweet bready aroma, with bready malt, alcohol, and citrus. Flavor of malty caramel, bread, and alcohol. Avg duration. Moderate alcohol finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Fair lacing.

A: Reddish copper with some nice head and lacing.

S: Somewhat hoppy and a decent amount of malty sweetness. Some dark fruits and sherry notes as well.

T: Malty sweetness and some mild earthiness alongside some pine and citrus hops.

M: A little hot, but overall not too bad. Its medium bodied and could definitely use some aging.

D: A nice sipper that improves a lot as it warms up, but still a little too much alcohol.

Bottle, from trade. Pours a deep red-ish amber body with a splendid, large off-white crown. Aroma is deep malty tones, honey, melon, hints of licorice, wood, candy sugars and cherries. A lovely scent. Taste is sweet licorice, deep malts, smooth cough syrup-like tones and hints of molasses and wood. Somewhat less complex than the aroma, but still very rich in flavor. However, the extreme drinkability is the strength of this brew. It is absolutely super-smooth and the high ABV is hidden like a Ninja, ready to pop out of the shadows and remind you of its strength only when its too late and youve had a bit more than you should. :-) This is an American BW in the same vein as the 3F/Mikkeller "Goop"-series; somewhat fruity and smooth in its hop profile while retaining a high level of smoothness, reminiscent of the English-style BWs. Once again a masterly crafted Ale from the Smiths we like so much. :-)

One of my favorite barley wines. Pours a beautiful bubbly mahogany with a white head that fades quickly and leaves a touch of lacing. It has a nosy and taste of sweet tropical fruits, caramel and honey. This beer is not hot at all and at 11% can turn you into a numbskull in a hurry if your not careful! This is a permanent want.

is that rarity i smell?? or the mold from the basement???  clear deep ruby with next to no head, no lacing, no real bubbles... loads of aroma, dark, malty, strong, not hot but distinct alcohol, fairly sweet, dark fruits, prune raisin fig style... not lively, full bodied, huge flavors, loads of dark fruit dominated by fig, masked alcohol, lightest of smoke, kinda finishes like a smoked fig which all of a sudden sounds awesome.. this is easily one of the better barleywines ive ever had, could use some liveliness, but it is drinkable for 11% without... finishes oily, not sweet or dry...

Bottle. Dark reddish-amber pour with light beige almost white head, beautiful. Aroma of toffee, molasses, alesmith yeast, aged hops. Very bitter flavor, lots of hop flavor with caramel maltiness and plenty of mouth coating alcohol warmth. Heavy bodied beer with good carbonation. American (hoppy) barley wines arent really my style, but Alesmith does it right.

Bottle. Hazy deep red/amber color with a full off white head. Nose of caramel, vanilla, and hints of dark cherries. Taste of bitter chocolate, with a bready sweetness and a big bitter finish. Long and creamy in the mouth with nice carbonation.

I have been saving this beer since last Thanksgiving.  I am super excited about this beer.  Pretty syrupy.  Dark mahogany color with a bubbly brown head.  Smell is very rich in molasses and brown sugar.  Some pine in the flavor as well.  Pretty rich in flavor.

Poured a deep reddish brown color with almost no head.  Big fruity aroma with lots of hops. Cotton Candy and pine as well.  taste is surprising smooth at first with hops and caramel.  Finish has pine and candy.  Maybe a little too sweet.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Strong aftertaste of lemons and grapefruit.  Very good and unique!

Purchased at Hyde Park Wine & Spirits in Cincinnati, OH; enjoyed on a work night grilling out with a good friend, couldnt picture a better moment to enjoy this.  Appearance a really dirty caramel brown with a rich off white/tan head.  Aroma rich in hops, the grassy/naturey variety, rich caramel malt in the back end.  Taste is an explosion of earthy hops, sweet caramel malt, and alcohol.  Also a nice dark fruit complexity in the back end, just really decadent and delicious.  Highly enjoyed.

Let me first say that hoppy beers are not my favorite. Bottle poured into a tulip glass. Pours a reddish brown color with a small head that melts into lacing around the glass. Nose is very complex: floral, herbal, caramel, sweetness and hoppy. Medium carbonation. Taste is very bitter. I dont see this as a barley wine. Interesting beer.

Bomber in the 2011 BarleyBlind tasting.  Had been cellared 6 months.  Pours orangey brown.  Aroma is chocolate and vinious.  Taste is plum, underlying sweetness, chocolatey with some alcohol present.  Quite smooth.  Finished #3 in the tasting, behind Hog Heaven and Behemoth.  Quite nice.

Draught sample.  Pours a clear light brown color with little light tan head. Aromas of dark fruit and alcohol.  Taste is not too boozy, but fruits, some rich sweetness.  Nice alcohol warmth.  Mouthfuls not too heavy for the style.  Overall, a very tasty sipper, would be great on a fall night.
Bottle, pours dark amber with a creamy tan head..aroma is sweet, fruits, barley and some caramel..... the flavor is pretty much the same as the nose :) very nice ...... love this!

15-07-11 Bouteille 750ml: Cuivrée brun, avec une bonne effervescence et une mousse splendide et abondante. Arômes typiques dune barley wine américaine aves ses fortes notes houblonnées, son malt caramel et une touche de confiture aux fraises. Très bien balancée avec une moyenne amertume et de bonnes notes maltées et caramélisés. Touche fruitée également présente. Corps parfait, avec une texture ronde et mielleuse et une finale plutôt légère comparativement à plusieurs barley wine. Très bon exemple de ce type de bière, cependant, suite à une bataille avec la Victory Old horizontal, la old numskull a du rendre les armes, ce qui peut expliquer que je ne lui ai pas attibué plus de point. Demeure une top barley wine!
Bottle: pours dark reddish-brown with a big frothy tan head, aroma is fruity and hoppy, taste is malty, dark fruit, slightly hoppy.  Delicious!

2010 750ml bottle. Cloudy red, faint light tan head. Surprisingly hoppy, some malt, bit of smoke but very nice. Bitter with some sweetness, nice dry finish, no hint of alcohol, very tasty. Seems more like a DIPA then a barleywine but we shall see how it ages.

plastic taster at alesmith.  thick head.  looks like a light orange.  smells of typical barley wine with a decent smell of citrus and fruits.  Taste is a lot of hops over fruity and smooth barley thrust.  so much hops its on the lines of an ipa if not for the obvious barley wine style maltness.  Really wish i had more than a taster of this!  great beer.  overall 8.5 of 10.

Hoppy sweaty feet aroma with caramel, salty grapefruit  and on slow deep inhales I hit sour cherry. Brew look mahogany gold with a thin skiff floating on top. Taste is not nearly as thick as I thought it would be. Taste is sweet citrus, hints of pine, massive woody malts. Just tasted so peach. Beer is coming across very sweet its not overly sweet but its close. Good very easy drinking B-winealmost to drinkable, however the epic flavor I was expecting and hopping for just wasnt here. Would gladly drink again.

2010 vintage. Ambery red with chunks, deep tan head of decent size and plenty of ropy and spotty lacing. Great hop citrus spice caramel peaches unsweetened grapefruit, light alcohol. Pretty good flavour with plenty of sweetness, alcohol, peach dulled, pine, grapefruit, malts. Goodness! Smooth and a touch rich, goes back way too easily. Yum time

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2016 Bottle from Dorothy Lane, very cloudy, deep honey color with a very nice head, very big anise and licorice taste, sweet but not overdone, alcohol plays a balanced role, very nice Barley wine.
Has finally come to PA. Bomber at Whole foods Wexford

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2012 750mL bottle, pours dark mahogany with a beige head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits, and strong hop characteristics. Flavour of plum, raisins, caramel, toffee and slight hops. Incredibly complex, smooth and hiding of the high ABV. Most excellent.

750 ml. bottle, shared at a group tasting. Poured a clear, deep copper color, with very modest, light tan head foam, and spotty lacing. The aroma was toasty, rich malt, dark fruit, some caramel, and a lurking alcohol presence. The flavor showed a touch of hop bitterness, but was overshadowed by the malty, brown sugar sweetness, and the very warming alcohol. The low carbonation didnt detract with so much else going on. Hefty bodied, and a very nice sipper!

Bottle shared by DalzAle (Greg). Pour is cloudy copper with a creamy off white head that slowly fades to a film a noticable lacing. Aroma is sugar malt and faint vanilla and coco. Taste is hops upfront with a sugary malty coco finish (awesome). Palate is fizzy creamy and finishes dry. This is amazing barley wine, I want more (Thanks Greg)!

750mL 2010 ed. The pour is a clearish, deep maroon blood ruby with a thick, dense, yellow head with excellent retention and sheety to wispy, sticky lace. Nose is salty, savory, toffee....oily flank steak, fatty meat, butter, marzipan, dried nougat, actually lots of heavy white chocolate and eggy lemon mousse- a first for a beer? Taste up front is saltwater toffee, sharp nutty bitter, walnuts, fresh and not cloying maple, milk chocolate, nougat, baked peaches. Palate is rich, buttery, bitter, dryish, non cloying, non syrupy. So fresh, oily, and quick on the palate. Mouthfeel perfection. Holy crap, I must have the bourbon version! Really just dominating in the American barleywine category.

pours an opaque dark caramel color with subtle ruby hues...medium tan head...nice lacing.  aroma is very hoppy with spicy and some citrusy hop notes...also some fig, dark fruit, a touch of vanilla, and alcohol.  flavor is notably roasty up front with caramely notes and raisins...sweet fruityness and also some earthy hop flavors towards the end...somewhat tea-like.  very warming finish that lingers with hops and dark fruit.

The beer pours a clearish medium brown with a light tan head. The head is gone quickly and the brown is not a very attractive looking color. 

The aroma is medium, very sweet and matly on the front. The end has a small but nice hoppy finish. 

The taste is a little lighter than the aroma, it actually starts pretty plain. The end has some hops.

The feel is pretty light.

Overall, this is a rather boring bw. It doesnt have the sweetness or balance of a great bw. I would skip this one.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2011 750 ml. Pours darker amber very little head. Nice dark fruit, cherry tartness and a ton of malt! A little floral on the nose as well. Honey, sweet malt and a ton of it, caramel, chocolate and some vanilla . A meduim mouthfeel and nice hoppy finish but not over bearing. This has been a long awaited beer for me and Im glad it lives up to the hype.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2011 Dark cloudy ruby red color with a creamy head.  Smells of cocoa, bitter hops, licorice, earth, bubblegum.  There is a light vanilla aroma as well.  Very smooth on the palate, strong bitter hops initially with the cocoa coming through nicely with vanilla.  Caramel malts, dark brown sugars, toffee, and molasses become notable before the finish.  The finish turns to bitter hops and the finish is long and dry.  Fantastic beer.

pours deep golden colour with slight whitish head.  Hop character dominates but nice sweetness (almost a caramel or toffee feel).  that would expect from a barley wine.  Nicely balanced and easy drinking.  Along the lines of a behemoth perhaps a bit sweeter and a little more earthy..  Very nice brew.

From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center Denver 16/09/2010
Hop aroma. Bronze golden coloured strong in alcohol and malty with a hint of bitterness in a warming finish.

2007 bottle drunk in 2011.   
Malt: nuts, molasses, toast, roasty, caramel
Hops: herbs
Other: alcohol, cherry, honey, maple syrup, plum, raisin
Color: orange, brown
Liquid: cloudy
Head: minimal, tan
Initial: medium bitterness, light sweetness
Finish: medium bitterness, medium sweetness, heavy sweetness
Finish Duration: average
Body: medium
Texture: dry
Carbonation: average
Finish: alcoholic

Bottled (thanks to whoever sent this to me, someone in the us... drewbeerme or jjpm74 afair...). Reddish amber colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is raisins, toffee, some mild hoppyness along with some earth and some stuff. Flavour is toffee, caramel, some mild alcohol, pleasant "old dead hops".

Bottled 750ml (vintage before 2007, ABV 11%)
Deep ruby color, small off-white head. Lots of raisins, alcohol and malts in the nose. Full-bodied. Caramel, raisins, roasted malts, alcohol. Very balanced. Ageing probably done good for this. Excellent.
Higly complex body and molasses sweetness makes this one of the best barleywines out there, highly recommended

Alcohol nose first,  Hoppy balanced with malt in the nose.  Northwest hop is more noticable at first too.  Bitter hop overpowers the malt, not in a bad way, its good.  Fruity ale taste.  Dry hop finish.

Sampled 12/21/2008 Ive had this bottle about a year, but Im not sure how old it was when I purchased it. I cant find anything on the bottle regarding a bottling date.
Pours a beautiful red color with a thin off white head that disappears quickly. Smells of Caramel and burnt sugar some citrus hops in there too. Tastes of Caramel, toffee, pine and grapefruit. Finishes kind of dry. Nice mild lingering malt and citrus. Mouthfeel is sticky and syrupy, body is medium, carbonation is low. Alcohol is very well hidden, dangerously drinkable. I love this Barley Wine.

Pours a dark brown color with decent lacing.  Nice hop profile with saweet malts on the nose.  Taste is the same very hoppy and great malt flavor.  The finish is dry yet smooth at the same time.  This is one of their best.

On tap at Alesmith.  Was surprised to find I hadnt rated this one.  Pours cloudy amber with a thin off-white head.  The nose is toffee and ripe citrus.  The taste is caramel, sweet citrus, light cocoa and pine.  Medium semi-creamy mouthfeel.  Very good.
750 from South Bay. Caramel and sweet barleywine that has done well in the cellar this past year. Mellow and malty taste. Very nice.

bouteille 75cl. Je pense que javais acheté cette bière en Californie en mai 2009. Lettres bleues avec Alesmith sous lenclume. Je pense que cette bouteille pourrait être plus vieille que anticipé.
Cuivre avec légère brume allant vers lorangée, mousse est fine beige.
Au nez, pas mal de malt et caramel, fruits avec un nez de beurre. Fruits avec une fine couche damertume et de citron.

En bouche, le bière est fine avec peu deffervescence. Note de malt et caramel et pas mal de levure et un fini donnant des notes de café. Je note aussi un palais granuleux du malt. Des fruits; prune, figues sont aussi présents avec un palais qui reste assez sucré et doux donnant une impression de miel, tirant vers le sirop de caramel et collant aux lèvres. Un peu faible au fini, limite plate. Garde un aspect terreux soit du miel ou de la levure accompagné damertume et en cherchant bien, un peu de soja. 
Le fond de la bouteille a une assez bonne couche de sédiments/levure. 
Un peu déçu. Je continue a me demander si cette bouteille nest plus âgée que ce que javais anticipé auparavant.
Very clear copper golden color with beautiful nice creamy head. Aroma is fresh ass hops, caramel roastiness, sweet candy sugars, brown sugar. Taste is sweet yet hoppy and malty. Awesome

Rating #1200. 2006 Bottle courtesy of drewbeerme. Pours a deep mahogany with fine rising carbonation and a creamy, beige head that leaves behind cascading lace. The nose is of dark fruit, rum raisin bread, dates and citrus hops. Full-bodied and velvety with fine carbonation and a sweet/bitter and drying finish that surprises me how much of the hop character remains after four-plus years. Big, sweet, dark fruity malt fronts the flavor profile that also includes citric hops and a candy sugar-like sweetness that pushes this beer into a liquid candy/English barley wine territory. While the hops still provide some counterbalance to the malt sweetness, I would really like to sample a fresher batch of this beer to see how much more aggressive the hop profile is/was when younger. As Ive come to expect from AleSmith... this is a damned fine beer. Thanks for the hook-up, Andrew.

11% ABV 750ml bottle, courtesy of Daknole (thank you so much for this GEM!!), served in a tulip.  Pour was a beautiful mahogany, which revealed nothing more when held to the light, with three fingers of large bubbled beige head; this brew also had a very nice show of lacing, as well as better than average retention.  Nose is caramel, candied sugar, dates, figs, malt, barley, notes of apple, a just a touch of wood.  Taste mimics the nose almost verbatim.  This stuff is just fantastic!  It is adheres exactly to my tastes when it comes to a barely wine.  Many are hoppy, which is not my preference, and some are so syrupy (which I enjoy to an extent) that it is almost like a milkshake (Dogfish head Olde School).  This is that perfect balance between the two that is right after my own heart.  It could only be better if it was aged in a bourbon barrel.  I really hope I can track down one (bourbon) in the near future ... amazing brew!

Poured into a snifter. Big thanks to hoppymcgee for this one. No sure what vintage this is.

3.5 A: Really dark amber color. Aggressive pour yielded slightly less than one finger of beige head. Average retention, but lots of lacing.

4.0 S: Lots of caramel sweetness and breadiness from the top. Plum fruitiness with a touch of orange citrus. Alcohol is pretty well hidden.

4.0 T: Like the nose caramel stands out, but the breadiness is at most slight. Theres some citrusy remnants of hops in the taste as well and the bitterness does well to balance out the malty sweetness. Not all that complex, but decent. The alcohol that was hidden in the nose comes out now in a big way.

3.5 M: Lighter heavy body, but sticky like a very heavy body. Carbonation is fine. Somewhat creamy. Finish gives a long lasting alcoholic bite and also a slight bitterness.

3.5 D: Not a bad brew, but the alcohol is a bit too apparent in the taste and it then becomes downright militant in the aftertaste. I wonder if aging this a few years to calm that down.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-27-2010 23:22:22

Pours with a heavier than expected beige head that leaves nice lacing. Deep copper color with aroma of sweet malt, raisins and substantial hops. Taste mirrors the aroma with a dash of alcohol presence.  Solid effort as expected by Alesmith.

Bottle; 2009 - Marked as 11% - Pour is cloudy dark brown/amber with a nicely colored tan head - average tan head, light lacing, nice retention. Aromas are piney hops, big caramel and toffee notes. Flavors are Resiny piney hops, big caramel malts, toffee, nutty bready notes, slightly boozy, honey, pineapple, and vanilla - Sweet and bitter initially, the hop presence does linger through the finish.

Bottle.  Big thanks to cbkschubert for this one.  Poured into my big snifter.  Dark burnt orange pour with a fluffy white head.  Big bubbles, left some lace and hung around for a bit.  Aromas were fruity as hell, caramels were quite prevalent too.  Then a hop presence arrived, light citrus and the regular pine.  Light booze.  The flavors were also quite fruity with a big caramel backbone.  Hops were there but didnt leave a real mark until the finish.  Nice light bitterness, smooth.  Carbonation soft, full mouth.  Another wonderful beer from Alesmith.  These dudes do NO wrong.

750 ml bottle. Pours a copper gold with a small creamy white head. Aroma is very rich fruit and candy notes, some brown sugar lots of caramel and just very sweet with some boozy notes, a nice assertive hop presence with some piney notes. Flavor starts with the very sweet and candied fruitiness. Picks up some earthy and fresh piney hops. Remains very rich with molasses and some nuttiness through the toasty and slightly boozy finish. Medium to full body and a softer carbonation. Good barleywine

Bottle. About two years on it.  Aroma of smooth sweet caramel, apricots, light booze.  Tasty. Faded pine and spruce. Big fruity barley wine with a throat warming booze .  Best barley wine Ive had in a good while.  Nice winter beer.
Great Barleywine. VERY hoppy. Big viscous body. Lots of toffee, caramel, biscuit, and pungent heavy hops. Almost like a DIPA. Sticky. Some honey. Another finely crafted Alesmith beer.

Vigorous pour produces a massive, creamy beige head that leaves resinous lacing down the sides of the glass.  Copper/red in the glass with aroma of sweet malt, raisin, date, honey, and clean bitter hops through the back end.  The aroma is potent but not obnoxious.  Taste follows the aroma with the addition of minor caramel and some toffee into the finish.  Small prick of alcohol at the end of the taste but very minor and does not take away from the flavor.  Excellent barley wine.
Aroma of roasted nuts and molasses. Strong orange marmalade taste with treacle, cloves, toffee, wood, and whiskey. Excellent barley wine.
Bottle with jredmond and patfannon. Pours a amber with no head. Flavor is boozey with vanilla and toffee Fla or. Slightly hippy and would do well with age.

Pours a hazy deep amber red with an off-white head.  Aroma is brown sugar,  caramel, sweet bread/malt, and hops.  Flavor is sweet malt, caramel, yeast, and bitter hops come through in the finish.  Very nice balance of the hops and barley wine malt profile. Good stuff
At a tasting, thanks Eyal, pours dark hazy orange with a giant tan head, aroma of pineapple, oranges and malt, flavor is bitter with tangerine, marmalade, throat burning and very sweet, full bodied.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a decent sized white head leaving a huge amount of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is a caramel sweetness with citrus hops.  Initial taste is a caramel sweetness followed by citrusy hops and bitterness.  Medium body.  Medium carbonation.

Bottle pours amber with an off-white head.  Aroma of pine caramelized peaches and booze.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of stone fruit and toffee.  Overall body is full, with moderate to heavy sweetness, and finishes with moderate to heavy bitterness.
At a tasting, thanks zvikar: lots of citrusy hops, grapefruit, rose water, caramel malt, the hops are a bit overpowering,  but still a very good beer, love the hops.

At a tasting, many thanks zvikar, medium stable head, extremely dark orange colour, that is a touch hazy but still quite clear, hoppy nose of pine and herbs with touch of malt at the end, flavours of jam,soap tobbaco and a hint of herbs, agressive and overbearing bittedrness, packering and hard to swallow. Much, much, much too bitter.
Bottle.  Pours caramel with orange notes, beige head, filmy.  Caramel.  All freaking caramel nose.  Sweet, sweet caramel, sugar, tootsie roll, mild to moderate bitter.  Freaking awesome.

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks zvikar. Hazy deep amber with a big off-white head. Aroma of flowers, pineapple ice pop, light citric notes and a bit of malt. Flavor is a a bit sweetish at first with some malt, a bit of caramel and cookies, and finishes with lingering hoppy bitterness, some pine needles and fruity notes. Medium to full-bodied.
750 ml bottle.  Clear amber color, no head.  Aroma of pine-sol (in a good way).  Taste is boozy, with lots of stone fruits.  Interesting.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Impressive stuff. Very powerful. Very sweet and bitter but fully balanced. Fruity, herbal. Intensive body and flavours but still very well drinkable.

Holy good god this is strong.  Caramel, dark raisins and fruits, bourbon, and so much more alcohol.  Maybe some coffee, who knows.  I feel like my teeth are going to fall out. You should drink this with some smores.

(750ml bottle) clear rich copper color with a very long lasting creamy tan head and excellent lacing. Nose of caramel, resinous pine, honey, bourbon, graham cracker and vanilla. Some grapefruit or orange hidden here as well. Complex and delicious smells. Taste of piney resins, orange rind bitterness, sweet caramel, burnt marshmallows, creamy, alcohol. Medium thick body, quite creamy, long duration and nice palate linger. Not my absolute favorite barleywine, but perhaps my favorite American style barleywine. I generally do not like hops in my barleywine, but this may be an exception to "as good as it gets". Still dont absolutely love it, but would drink it again anytime!

Bottle of the 2006.  Not quite flat, but pretty low carbonation.  Very rich, nutty(pecans) aroma.  Surprisingly still a good amount of hops as well as alcohol heat (only 10%!?!)  Medium light sweetness.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, floral hops, citrus, caramel, & spice; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, rich spicy hops, caramel, citrus (notably grapefruit), dark fruit, and some licorice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced and complex; The alcohol is fairly well hidden; Overall, excellent barley-wine.

Finally cracked this one open for the birth of my son on Sept 29th. I had been cellaring this for over a year since I bought it around Aug of last year. Barley wines are not my fav style, not something I hate mind you, just not something I always want to have, usually a two or three times a year beer for me. This was a wonderful light brown to red color and the smell of flowery hops and almost brownie-like malts after poured into a snifter. First taste is almost imperial ipa with the flowery hop taste that is almost standard for alesmith, and the malts kick in on the middle to back of the tongue. The clean ethanol warmness of the abv is evident just after the sip goes down like a nice mild brandy, but it is also well hidden so that its not too overbearing. I was going to enjoy this one anyways due to the occastion that it was opened, and like I said to my wife, "i know my obfectivity is out the window on this one, but its absolutely delicious." Even better when shared with my father at the birth of his first grandchild.

Silver wrapper, Blue printing

A: poured into a snifter and allowed to warm a little. The barleywine pours a clear, mahogany color with some small flaky sediment floating around. small halo of off-white head clings to the glass.

S: very resiny and hoppy aroma. nice thick and warming scent of wonderful citrus hops mostly overly ripe oranges. Some black pepper, some big pine aromas. This is what a barleywine should smell like.

T: such a smooth, well-balanced flavor. Tons of citrus hops right off the bat, with perfect malt flavors to balance it out. Strong citrus flavors are still lingering. Some big pine flavors, along with some of that black pepper from the aroma.

M: Very smooth and clean, as well as being rich and thick. perfect low carbonation level.

D: for 11% this is extremely drinkable. I am not sure why this isnt the standard for barleywines, since it is absolutely amazing. I always like BWs, but this just made me love them.

Pours with a light- to medium-bodied head that sticks around for a bit.  Lots of hops in the aroma - pine and floral notes.  Caramel and chocolate come through with almost a hint of licorice.  Taste is more malty and has a nice alcohol kick, much more like a barleywine.  The the hops add more bitterness to the taste than anything else, with the exception of some pine.  Very nice beer and should age nicely.

Bottle pours murky amber color with tan head.  Aroma is citrus and bitter.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is upfront very bitter, resinous, has a very solid backbone of malt, and finishes bitter.  This was a bruiser of a beer.   The honey sweetness, toasty aroma, and full body make this a real winner.  Great brew.

750 ml bottle.  Had this bad boy all to myself.  Pours a clear brown with a tan head.  Nose is of roast malt, hops and caramel.  This has a perfect nose for a barleywine.  Taste is of roast malt and hops.  Mouthfeel is medium and bitter.  Loved this.  Wish I had more.

Cloudy, dark-amber color with a light, fine off-brown colored head.  An awesome hop-alcohol aroma.... heavy on the nose, really - very nice!  Flavor is light hop/malt... extremely easy for a barley wine, really.  SO easy!  Im really surprised at how delightfully welcoming this beer is... and the alcohol is almost undetectable!

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2010 For your less hoppy Bwines, this is damn tasty even for this hop lover.   Pours amber, light brown haze with an off white foam head.  Has an aroma of toffee, dark fruit, and brown sugar.  Has a candy sweet taste with some gentle bitters on the back end.  The alcohol comes through, but this Bwine is not too boozy.  Has a nice creamy mouthfeel.  Delicious.  Perhaps a year of agining will mute the alcohol notes some, but good now if you cant wait.

Bottle. 24.5 oz. Split with James. Pours a deep ruby amber with a rich, full, frothy beige head. Aroma of sweet malts, molassess, brown sugar, caramel, honey, roast, and a bit of citrusy hoppiness. Medium to fuller bodied with a full, sticky, bittersweet palate. Finishes smoothly with a small burn down through the chest. Good barley, but overrated.

aroma is bursting with fresh hops backed by toffee, caramel apples, roasted nuts, and alcohol.
cloudy orange brown with foamy beige head.
full of flavor, but not overly bitter or sweet--very nicely balanced for a barley wine.
medium body, slightly chewy and silky, long alcoholic caramelized hop finish.

750ml bottle in a snifter.  Pours brown with beige head.  Aroma of pine hops and some caramel/bread malts.  Flavor has the bitterness of the hops and a little sweetness from the malts.  Full bodied.  Great beer.
True to beer making  @ Alesmith this is an awesome barley wine.  Toffee and caramel aromas and flavors.  Alcohol is well integrated.  Overall  a pretty freaking awesome beer.

Poured from a liter bottle into a relatively large snifter. Aroma is heavy on floral hops and a bit of dried fruit. Raisins may be the scent I am noticing. Appearance is an opaque brown that allows no light through. At first pour the head is about 3/4 inch in height that dissipates to just a thin lacing on the top of the beer until the end. Hops jump out in the taste of this beer but more mellow than that of an IPA. There is also a bit of the dried fruit originally noticed in the nose. The body of this is that of a giant. This is a huge beer with a huge flavor and that does not go unnoticed anywhere in the beer. For such a high abv beer, you really cannot notice it in the taste. Love this beer but it is definitely a sipper.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2011 Location/Date:Beer split with Dave on November 30th, 2011.  Bottle.
Appearance: Pours a dark maroon.
Aroma: Aroma is of malt of caramel and honey.
Taste: Malty, caramel,lighter bitterness, somewhat sweet.
Palate:Medium heavy body, lingering boozy finish.
Summary: A nice barelywine, finally get to update my rating with a coherent tasting.

750 ml bottle. 2009 vintage. 08.24.10

Pours deep mahogany reddish brown with a frothy thick mildly tan head. The nose is juicy pineapple, dried apricots, raisins, caramel bready malt, toffee, brown sugar, piney hops, mild chocolate cherry, and carameled apples. The taste is initially pineapple, apricot, and raisin that transitions into piney hops, bready caramel malt, and toffee. The beer finishes with a moderately dry, piney hop taste and a lingering caramel malt. The palate is wonderful; a velvety smooth, and creamy mouthfeel with a perfect amount of carbonation. A wonderful BW. Perhaps my favorite (even over Bourbon Barrel Angels Share).

750ml, silver foiled bottle, 2009 edition from south bay. bout damn time i opened this one up, huh? pours a hazy, reddish-gold with a massive, rocky, off-white head that leaves thick sheet of lace. aroma is absolutely wonderful, amazingly fruity and fresh for over a year old, with big, bright notes of candied pineapple, apricots, and tropical fruits dipped in sweet caramel with notes of honey, pine resins, dry hops, and burnt toffee and just a touch of sweet, sugary, bready malts. flavor is fantastic and so unique with big, spicy hops and huge, juicy fruit notes of pineapple, red apple, and peach skins up front backed by smooth, sweet caramel malts, yellow raisins, dried apricots, prunes, and spicy pine with a touch of burnt toffee on the finish. palate is full bodied, perfectly carbonated, and sticky/sweet on the tongue with beautiful finish of caramel-dipped fruits. overall a fantastically unique barleywine. cannot wait to pop my barrel aged bottle!

Deep amber/brownish pour creamy light tan head aroma of caramel malts, vanilla and light citrus hops.......... lots of caramel malt in the taste also dark fruit and vanilla but overall a very rich malty caramel brew with a warming alcohol and some citrus hop quality in the bitter finish.... a full bodied and enjoyable barleywine that Id imagine would be rated higher if aged

750 ml Bottle. Aroma is toffee, dates, brown sugar, and woody alcohol. Appearance is a reddish nut brown color with an inch of frothy head and thick lacing patterns around the glass. Taste begins with fresh caramel and herbal hops flavors along with raisins, toasted malt, candied figs, honey, vanilla, pine resin and alcohol. Mouthfeel is slightly syrupy and sticky with low-to-medium carbonation and a malty, alcohol warming finish. The overall flavor is exceptionally complex with an excellent balance between the malt and hop flavors and the 11% ABV level is quite subtle. Its an outstanding West Coast interpretation of an English Barleywine that should satisfy both malt and hop fiends alike.

Bottle courtesy of Secret Santa, Christmas 2009. Pours a mahogany color with a thin off white head and a touch of lace. Aroma is caramel malt, vanilla and dark fruit.  Warm and heavy on the palate with low carbonation. Flavor is caramel, toffee, brown sugar and dark alcohol soaked fruit . Wonderful drinking experience.

The nose is fruity, woody, citrusy, bread.  The appearance is a slightly hazy yet translucent red, off-white head.  The flavor is fruity, boozy, citrus and pine, earth, wood.  The flavor is booze warming, piney hop bittering, which endures.  The mouthfeel is oily, medium/thick to thick in body.  Solid BW, but it doesnt live up to the hype, imho.  Nothing unique or unusual.  This MUST be better after maybe a year in a dark cellar.

Bottle shared with MatSciGuy (Thanks Levi!) Dark hazy amber pour, little carbonation and a nice stone fruit/malt aroma.  Flavor is rich dark malts, boozy plums, some spice and finished good and boozy/malty.  Solid beer, I liked this way more than the BA version.

(750ml bottle).  Dark amber/orange color with off-white head.  Aroma of resin, alcohol, some funk.  Taste is slightly sweet with some noticeable hops.  Medium bodied with somewhat thin.  Finish is slightly bitter and noticeable alcohol warmth.  Nice barleywine.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
boozy, warms the chest when you drink it, lots of toffee, not so much caramel, hints of vanilla, nice hop bite.

Bottle shared with coworkers.  Pours a hazy brownish orange with a medium beige head.  Malty and slightly sweet with vanilla and caramel.  Medium bodied, lots of toffee and caramel.  Long brutally bitter finish.

Bottle (75 cl), thanks Marsiblursi. Deep clear mahogny, yellow beige head. Caramelly,and a bit sugary, with dried fruits, and spicy, citric hops. Medium boied and smooth. Low to medium sweetness, medium to high bitterness. Well done.

Appearance- dark, golden amber color

Smell- syrup, citrus and a nice hoppy bitterness

Taste- Hops, syrup

Mouthfeel- thick and syrupy. ver little carbonation

Overall- Fantastic barleywine!

Bottle. Pours hazy deep amber/brown, medium off-white head, lovely lacing, Nose is floral hops, chocolate, dark fruit, cherries, brandy beans. Flavors are spicy florals, rich tawny port, chocolate, fruitcake. Very nice, not the equal of the BA version, but very nice.

Mahogany brown pour with a minimal white head.  Sweet brown sugar, vanilla, dates, some hop presence on the aroma. Slightly woody, smooth woody and vanilla notes, sweet toffee, mild dark fruit flavors, finishes with balancing hops and a warm, not harsh, alcohol finish.  Fairly smooth and pleasant as the style goes.

Wonderfully fruity and hoppy aroma with wood and caramel, chocolate. Flavor is woody and dry, with fruit and caramel. Complex and very dry with a long finish that is slightly harsh and alcoholic. Great, but the mouth lags behind the nose, and I imagine this will be better in a couple years.

Pours a dark amber with a big creamy lacing head. The aroma was fruity when it was cold but changed to a more malty essence as it warmed. The flavor changed with the temp as well. Wine like and fruity at first but as it warmed the flavor became more malty sweet with caramel, vanilla. The hops kicked in at the end. Incredibly smooth with no hint of the alcohol laying in wait. A kick ass beer and thanks to Hawthornes in Philly for getting it to the east coast.

Murky brown pour. Aroma of caramelized sugar, more burnt than normal, soaked in a raison alcohol bath. Flavor is focused a bit more on fig and prune, with big hot hops and toffee. Boozy, yes again. Quite nice!

750mL bottle, ~2yrs old.  DATE YOUR DAMN BOTTLES ALESMITH!!!   Pours a dark red translucent amber with a few fingers of head.  Aroma is quintessential barleywine, lots of raisins, caramel, malt, sweet fruit and alcohol.  Tastes just like it smells, sweet raisins, alcohol, malty, and a nice bitter malty finish.  Solid barleywine.

Review from notes. 2007 vintage bottle shared with a couple of the Chicago crew. Poured from bottle into snifter tasting glass.

A - Pours a reddish/copper color, a bit of off-white head, some decent lacing and a ultra-thin cap on top with some bubbles around the edge of the glass.

S - Perfectly balanced blend of sweet candies, malt, burnt sugars, and some dark fruit notes. 

T - Again, the age on this has done wonders. Candies, burnt sugars, malts, dark fruit, vanilla. Maybe a touch of alcohol, but its very well hidden and is perfectly balanced. Sweet finish.

M - Medium body, oily and sticky, rich, syrupy finish.

D - At 11%, Im amazed how easy this was to put down. One of the best English BWs Ive had the pleasure to taste. If you have a bottle from or around 2007, its on.

Bomber from Blind Tiger. 2008. Cloudy dark brown with medium white head. Aroma is sweet molasses syrupy booze, brown sugar, toffee, faint darker fruits, sweet cane sugars. Taste is huge sweet dried fruit with syrupy booze background. Burns boozy down throat. Awe-inspiring and shocking, totally freaky.

A: The pour is a dark amber color, bordering on brown, with a fluffy off-white head.

S: A fresh citrus hop aroma, primarily grapefruit. In the background (and the essence of the beer) are great notes of brown sugar, toffee, caramel, and perhaps dark fruits.

T: The flavor opens up with great sweet malt, caramel, and toffee. This is followed by a grapefruit citrus flavor and a piney bitterness on the finish.

M: The body is definitely on the full side with a smooth and moderate level of carbonation.

D: Im not always the biggest barleywine fan, but Alesmith has a proven winner with Old Numbskull. I especially enjoy it fresh, but with some age (or from a barrel) its delicious as well.
One of the best barley wines Ive ever had.  Drinks smooth as silk and has a really nice warm finish.  Even with a high alcohol content it still slides downyour throat.

Glowing clear reddish brown, aroma is sweet malt and a faceful of grapefruity hops. Very floral and very resiny. Flavor is very malty but not heavy, the hops have more presence than the malt. Refreshing. Bottle from Pizza Port, Carlsbad bottle shop in San Diego.

Bottle shared by Rustyham. Pours cloudy caramel color with off white head. Aromas of citrus hops and caramel malts. Sweet caramel flavor with grapefruit and dark fruits. Medium to full body with average carbonation. Thanks Nick.
Bottle at RBNAG-2009. Amber colour with a beige head. Aroma is verylike the flavour. Hop, coffee, licorice, malt, caramel, alcohol. Full bodied world class beer.
Very tasty.  Delicious caramel malts but not too sweet.  I think I like it a little more than Green Flashs Barleywine, but its too slight a difference to justify >2 x the price.
touch of resin in the nose with hints of malt backing. creamy head. Not a lot of sweetness.

Bottle, 75cl, at RBNAG -09. It pours a hazy, almost copper body under an off-white head. Peppery hops, lovely piney and resiny scents, and lots of malty sweetness on the nose. The flavor is really intense and well balanced, with lots of peppery, resiny hops giving a lingering bitterness, and a beef-stocky malty sweetness as a base. Full-bodied and warming, pleasantly carbonated. Lasting finish where caramel sweetness and piney hops blend nicely. Good bitterness too. The alcohol is with you all the way, but never gets out of hand, making this beer a real treat, one that every beer lover should have available at all times. I certainly wish I had. 091107

750ml bottle of probably either the 08 or 09, labeled as 11% abv. Pours clear amber with a huge thick foamy beige head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, citrus and alcohol. Flavors follow the scent with lots of sweet caramel malt, citrus and pine hops and a definite alcohol presence. Medium body with average carbonation and long finish of bitter hops and alcohol. Another great beer from Alesmith, still a bit hot, I would like to get another bottle and hold onto it for years.

Thanks to slasher007 for sharing this bottle and thanks to kaiser81 for sending the bottle to him.

The beer pours a reddish-amber color with a medium-sized white head. The aroma is much hoppier than expected, with citrus hops, brown sugar and sweet malt. The flavor is more of the same. The beer tastes like oranges covered in a brown sugar glaze. The hop flavor is high but the bitterness is pretty low. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

2007 or 2008 bottle.  Poured a clear yellowish brow with a small off-white head, soapy lace.  Aroma is hot booze, caramel malt, dark fruit.  Taste is also of sweet malt, dark fruit, more booze.
