Dark fruits came up big, and alot more hop presence than I expected.  A very nice beer indeed, but not my favorite barleywine or alesmith brew.

Thanks to TChrome for this one.  Alesmith beers, to me, are like women with their ankles behind their ears....I just find them irresistable.  This one pours slightly turbid ruby, with a big of-white head.  Aroma of malt, tons of fruit, hops, cognac, cabernet, black pepper.  Tastes malty, very fruity, with a finishing warming sensation at culmination.  I noted cherries, berries, scotch, black pepper, jalapenos, cognac, cabernet, oak, vanilla, caramel, and almonds in the mid to late palate.  SMooth finish with a slight astringency and a very slight surfactant edge.  This one is great, but Im not sure it beats the complexity of Hair of The Dog Doggie Claws and Heavyweight Old Salty, or the smoothness of Full Sail Barleywine, or the mishmash heavy hitter aspect of Avery the Beast, but its right up there with all of them.  Id love to try these side by side with all these.  Then again, if you did a "side-by-side" with all those, youd be passed out in the crotch of Star Jones.  This is an awesome barleywine.  One of the best.  Dont miss it!  Thanks again, Tad.  You rule!  Yeah man!

Sampled immediately prior to trying the BA Numbskull.  Woo and all.  Reddish, a bit hazy.  Great nose, butterschotchy malts, some hops, tart and powdery sugars.  Good flavor, quite sweet with toffee and maple syrup.  Some definite hops there, but the toffee hangs around beautifully in the mouth.  Syrupy.  Nice stuff.
Nice caramel vanilla that is well balanced throughout each glup....Poundable.

Sampled at jeffc666s gathering. 2003 bottle. Cloudy amber with some suspended particles and an off white head. Aroma of some alcohol, caramel, vanilla and pineapple. Taste has many of the aroma qualities plus notes of dark fruit, brown sugar, pine,  grapefruit/hops, toasty malt and a hint of roastiness. Mouthfeel is full, round and smooth with subtle carbonation. Really good stuff.

Bottle sampled at jeffc666s B-day gathering 2/6/05:  2003 bottle.  Hazy amber color, almost no head, with many medium particles visable in the glass.  Aroma: vanilla, pine, pineapple, sweet caramel, sweet sticky hops, apples, pears.  Flavor: salty hops, then more hops, backed up by sweet caramel, grains, honey, apple, and wood.  Very smooth and slick.

On the back of the bottle it says to age for 6-24 months. I didnt do that. It says "do not refridgerate until ready to drink" Oops. It says to leave the brewers yeast in the bottle. Looks like I was wrong again. So, after apparently messing up in every conceivable way, Did the stuff stand a chance? Oh yeah. Pours a brilliant but cloudy copper with minimal head. Big caramel and toffee aroma, with significant notes of fresh hops, vanilla, and charcoal. The first flavor is peppery, salty, piney citrus hops. Smooth, viscous malt flavors emerge as it warms, as do notes of cognac. The caramel that was prevalent in the aroma emerges slowly in the mouth, much more of a bit player. The palate is nearly perfect - oily, but just the right amount of carbonation. Really impressive beer.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2005  Where do I begin with this?  Really cool looking brown pour with very little head.  The head looks like caramel.  The aroma has that recognizable Ale Smith sweetness to it.  I must say I am quite impressed with the aroma because it is fruity and also has a hard liquor element to it.  The taste is very strong in terms of the alcohol.  It reminds me more of hard liquor then beer.  Its great though and from the best brewery in the world.  Quite good, but a little too strong for me in terms of the alcohol.  There is still a smoothness to it despite the strength of the alcohol.  This brewery is awesome and I want to get my hands on more of their stuff.  This just gets better everytime I have it.
Yet another beer from Great American Beer Festival.  Picked another beer because of a weird name.  Yellow/orange with a little off-white head.  Aroma of pine - another one bottled in a state park.
One of my favorite Barleywines.  Little to no head, little to no lacing.  Great taste but you can feel the burn from the alcohol.  Fairly strong.

This is a really good barleywine that is tops on my list of Barleywines that I have tried.  Its a really luxurious and full bodied beer with amazing taste.  I would love to try the Barrel Aged version if I can find it.  This is a top notch barleywine that cant be passed over.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2005 Hazy brown-prune body under a minimal white head.  Aroma is of dark fruity malts, rasinis, and brandy.  Maybe a bit of sock, too.  Milky-sweet flavor with rasinis and plums with a woody, hoppy finish.  Theres a vodka-alcohol element too but it doesnt interfere with the flavor.  A malty take on the barleywine style, me like.

a touch cloudy and a deep red color, a large bubbled sparse head.  scent was fairly strong contained hints of raisens malts sweet fruityness and very little hops that tend to be prevelant in a barley wine the palate is creamy w/ little carbonation and a sweet finish w/ a hint of alcohol down the throat.  taste was a hoppy salty almost flavor w/ a taste of plum fruitiness and a goad roasted malt backing.. as the glass warms hints of alcohol come out along w/ the raisen flavor.  Overall this is a great beer but not one of the best barely wines Ive had.

Hazy black-ruby with no head but some yellowy suds around the circumference.  Aroma spicy-raisiny malt with some pine and a little citrus and notes of watermelon and strawberry.  At first, theres a salty hops feel followed by strong pine flavour that does not comandeer the taste, but gives way to a sweet raisiny aged malt that leaves one licking his lips.  The bitterness is quite significant and offsets the smoothness somewhat.  Medium to full body with gentle carbonation, but a little mouth puckering from all the hops.

2003 vintage:  cloudy brownish gold w/very short head.   vinuous and light caramel malt aroma.  flavor is sweet vinuous and plum/prune, toasted caramel malt, faint alcohol heat.  hops only on the edges, thats how I like it.

Pours a cloudy, caramel brown color with no head. Great aroma of caramel, hops and alcohol. Amazing flavor of malt, caramel, fruit, hops and alcohol with a bitter finish. Medium body, syrupy and sticky texture, very soft carbonation. I could slowly sip this beer forever ...
Aroma of dark fruit. Tastes very nice and sweet with a toasted caramel present. Very warming and enjoyable.

Poured a hazy amber with a small off white head.  Appears thick and oily and sticks to the glass.  Aroma is malt foward.  Sweet, fruity, and notes of honey.  Sweet, malty, caramel flavors start it off.  This then turns to fruit and gives a well balanced finish of honey, bitterness, and alcohol (both flavor and warming sensation).  Body is full with a light syrupy feel.  It happens to be a great night for this beer.  I am in a cabin in the mountains.  It is 15 degres and there is a chance of snow.  But i am nice and warm..or should I say toasty.

In addition to the BA version I tasted, I also tasted 2 bottles (Vinages 03 & 99) of this beer. Poured an amber color with an off white head. Aromas and tastes of raisins, plums, alcohol, and caramel. Sweet.

Pour was a deep ruby with a nice tan head that laced well...smell is pine hoppy with lots of plum, smoke, oak, caramel,and alcohol...taste was sweet and young with alcohol...also a definate hoppy warmth...lots of alcohol here...good though...

Aromas of plum, malt and slight twinge of alcohol.  Bottle is aged enough that the hops are almost nonexistent.  Tons of malt and dried fruit come through.  Carbonation almost gone with a rigorous pour.  Medium bodied, nothing too cloying.  Slight alcohol kick in the finish. Quite nice.

Poured a light brown with almost no head. Big aroma of alcohol and malted milk balls. Flavor was a little "hot" and hoppy, but really nice with lots of citrus, pine resin, and malt. The flavor was made even better by a full palate without being too sticky and just the right amount of carbonation. Im very grateful to mjames for bringing this one back for me.

New Years Eve 2004 beer #2.  Best name I have heard for a barleywine yet.  Pours a lot lighter color than I expected.  Nice head/lacing.  Lots of resiny citrus aroma here, with warm toasted malt aroma and alcohol emerging as it warmed.  Excellent mouthfeel.  Beady, soft carbonation along with toasty malt, carmel, and a big dose of hop resin.  Finshes with a note of alcohol and lingering malt sweetness.  Excellent.  I think I want to lay one of these down for a few years and see how it progresses.

Big hazy dark chestnut body.  Rich in both malts and hops, with a mild appearance from the alcohol.  Not hyper-carbonated, as befitting the style, but hyper-smooth.  Vinous, dark fruits (dates), wood, and a crispy, deep-fried, burnt edge.  The mid-finish isnt super-complex, but otherwise this is a wonderful concoction. (2004 Christmas Party, my #3, groups #4)

strong candy and alcohol aroma, brown/red with a nice looking head, very balanced, delicate on the palate, earthy and warming with growing alcohol strength and increasing stickiness, nothing too complex, well crafted but somehow lacking, severely overhyped
From top to bottom this was an outstanding ale.  I love the rich texture and the balance of hops and malt.  What a great beer to share the Chritmas season.

Intense ruby red ale with no head or carbonation. Raisin and c-hops aroma, with notes of prunes and vanilla. Sweet malt and c-hops, prunes, fruity, with notes of chocolate. Balanced alcohol warmth with piney hops. Smooth and treachurous barley wine. Thanks to Sickboy.
stong aroma of candyish alc and brandy.  Orange burgundy color, minimal head.  Very nice, piney, moderately bitter hops.  Malts are light carmel, a bit stickey, moderate toasty flavors, Nice.

Very Dark very bubbly for a Barleywine, strong rich malty aroma with a note of grape. Smooth texture for all the bubbles, light malt taste that became dry and the alcohol made itsel evident. Bet it will taste better when its a little older
Not my favorite barley wine... but maybe that was do in part to the 13 dollar price tag =(  I am a poor boy dammit!

750 ml green bottle with a silver foil wrapper covering the cap, I believe this is a 2003 vintage but cannot find a date to verify this. This beauty pours a dark reddish brown color with a collar of light tan. The collar leaves nice lace about the glass. The aroma is sweet with caramel and dark fruits with a good amount of alcohol as well. There is a lot more going on here that I would have to drink another one to most likely identity in this very complex and wonderful smell. The taste has a big sweetness up front that tastes of caramel, rich fruits and spiciness. The hops are present and become more evident as this one warms and creates a bitter dry finish. Mouthfeel is thick and rich and has decent carbonation. This is a very smooth barley wine that seems to improve with age from what I have read. It is excellent at the point it is now with a very complex nose and taste and a surprisingly smooth finish, I can only imagine how it could improve.

(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy brown with a small bubbly white head.  Aroma of caramel, citrus, toffee, butterscotch, soy sauce, brown sugar, and vanilla.  Cognac-like qualities with hops and spices.  Outstanding barley wine!

2003. Murky brown color with no head.
Sweet aroma of malt, molasses and dark fruits. Flavor was not as sweet as expected. Starts off slightly sweet, with the flavor of malt, molasses, figs and
caramel. Then it dries quickly with a nice hoppy finish. Very enjoyable, to say the least. Have 2 more bottles and cant wait to see how this one ages.

I had the 2000 vintage of this and it was fantastic.  The cork actually fell apart on the way out and the inital aroma as that of a nice red wine.  The flavor was well balanced and really great.  This was a wonderful beer and I am really glad that I had the opportunity to try it.

Vintage 2000. Drank October 30, 2004.
Brown/Amber..Cloudy Coloring.  No Head.  Good Barley Aroma and Flavor.  Good Standard for Barley Wines.  Although a Tad on the Sweeter Side of Things...  Wonderful Malts and Presence of Alcohol... Great one to Enjoy on Those Cold Nights.

Red brown w/little or no head. Fruit, carmel, mint and hops on teh nose. Med weight w/sweet mid palate and drying finish. Flavors of Cherry, mint, chocolate, yeast, burnt toast and some alcohol heat on the finish. Awesome beer!

RBMNG 10.03.04. Alas, my first Alesmith beer. And I picked a good one at that. 2000 vintage. Somewhat sour aroma. Smells Belgian. Despite 10% abv, alcohol is not overly prevelant in the nose. Beautiful amber color. Small, off-white head. Nice lace. Wonderful, high alcohol mouthfeel. Caramel notes. Refined for a barley wine. Outstanding.

Bottled 2000 Vintage; Tasted October 30, 2004:  Hazy mahogany color with no head.  Sweet malt aroma.  Very malty taste, but it was quite sugary.  Not a syrup sweet like some other barley wines, but certainly sweet.

2000 bottle.Trade from cciuroga.looked like murky apple cider,fresh squeezed.Strong notes of caramel, toffee,fruits,malts and hops.I tell ya,I was much more impressed with the complexity of the flavor of this then I was of the aroma.The body is thick and syrupy laden with the swetness of toffee and a chewy honey caramel candy I had called Bito Honey.But there
an underlying bitterness from the hops that put the brakes on this getting blown out by sweetness.

Pours a cloud deep red, thin tan head. The nose is full of berries, sweetness, flowers, and a touch of alcohol. Tastes of malt, hops, alcohol, honey hit at first, and then finish with a bitter hops bite.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2005 color murky dark brown, no head, aroma stale old  flavour malty sour a little old hop flavour finnish alcohol and stale malt flavour maybe a old,baddly handled bottle I was hoping for a lot more

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2006 the numbskull has a very dark color letting no light through what so ever.also not having any head at all.the first tatse was very smooth,especially for a barley wine.it also didnt have the strong syrup taste that some barley wines have.just a smooth start and nice fruity afertaste with a hint of alcohol.yet another winner from alesmith.
RE-RATE ON 6-03-06 OF A 2003 BOTTLE:light carbonation with alot of caramel/chocolate flavors in the flavor.plus a little honey,hops and yeast.alcohol is totally hidden and the palte is slightly oxidized.

An unclear dark amber beer with no head. The aroma is very hoppy, sweet, and malty. The flavor is very sweet and very hoppy = very simple, and with alcohol burning the tongue. For me, this is too simple.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2005 I brought this over to my friends last night and we split it. It poured a hazy dark peach. The head was creamy and dense and laced well.

The nose was great. At first, I couldnt smell anything but knowing that is allergy season I blew a bunch of shit out of my nose then resmell it and the nose was definatly there. Very fruity and citrusy hop nose. Somewhat floral with cherries and cinnamon apples.

The flavor was outstanding. Tons of dark fruits. This beer was juicy and big and massive and the flavor never stopped in the mouth. Not once. Ripe fruits, a little banana with black cherries. Finish was long lasting. Big in the mouth. .................................................. The last three bottles I have opened have been very poor, one suffered from oxidation, the other were just very thin and one dimensional.  All three were undrinkable, so I am lowering my score for now.  Whats going on with Alesmith lately?
Clear amber color with a beige head. Sweet aroma of caramel and hops.  Strong hop flavor with some malt, candy and raison flavors in the background.

Easily one of the most well balanced BWs that I have experienced. Very smooht- too smooth almost. The alochol is quite apparent, but this isnt bad- I wanna know sometimes that my brew is gonna kick my ass.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2007 Bottle. Beautiful garnet pour. Notes of sweet cherry, oak, mellow hops, raisin/prunes come through. Has a very smooth mellow slightly bitter finish. This is am excellent beer.  (original #s: 9/4/9/5/19).  Re-rate 8/18/07; bottle shared with fly: Murk brownish orange body, medium-high bitter, husky, dirty, hops very much upfront and the malt is much more retsrained than I remeber. Borwn sugar, mollasses, rust, nutmeg, cinnamon, vinegar. Not as enjoyable as a remember it being, but still top notch.

pours a cloudy light amber with a minimal light tan head. malt is very evident in this sweet sugary aroma that reminds me of sweet tart candy and bubble gum. flavor is also sweet, caramel and honey jumped out at me, also notes of toffee and earthy flavors. fruity ambrosia is something else i jotted down in my notes. this had a wonderful mix of competing flavors that were in harmony. has a luxorious thick mouthfeel. leaves some bitter on the finish that keeps this from being onesided. the flavor complexities are amazing. sweet fruits mingle with chocolate and toffee then give way to an enveloping almost orange tasting citrus hop. the finish on this blew me away. nothing has left such a wonderful lingering flavor before. marvelous. Thanks to TChrome for this one.

Dark brown cloudy liquid with a neat lasting fine head.  Nose is plenty of hoppy acrid tang.  Flavor is a complex carmel and hop symphony with good malt middle.  Texture is smooth and full.  Finish is tangy hops and medium roast malt happiness.

Red brown color with a thin layer of foam on top.  The aroma has a strong feeling of earthy tones, sugars and fruit.  The first small sip made me feel all warm inside.  Pleanty of coffee and cocoa feeling is left in the mouth from a closing to the beer that is bitter and crisp.  I think my quarrel with this beer is that it doesnt have a great initial taste and feels a tad on the thin side.  It certainly is enjoyable more than most beers, but I still prefer the old horizontal.

So Im really confused as to why this is rated so high. I mean, I love barleywines but this stuff just doesnt do it for me. Its big, its sweet, its malty, the 10% ABV puts the hurt on but I found this to be somewhat lacking in flavor and complexity. It smells nice with whiffs of raisin, molasses, honey--really, all things malty but the palate is somewhat flat and boring, the color dull and dark and the hop presence a bit too reserved (not always a problem but in this case the beer definitely needed some more spunk).

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2005 August 04:  750 ml capped bottle, no apparent date.but probably 2003-4.  Murky, nearly opaque dark ochre with yeast particulates vaguely evident, virtually no head.  Massively vinous aroma, deep burnt caramel evident on second nosing, slight hints of bitter orange, alcohol and cocoa.  On the tongue, restrained bitterness, caramelly sweetness in the background, firm malt and a light herbal quality.  Strong alcoholic and hoppy burn towards the finish; a little on the thin side  This is far from a knockout for me...on the whole, Im not so blown away by this brewery to date.  Very average barley wine with the aroma being the most distinguishing feature. 3.5 total

Jan 2005:  pretty much the same...still a bit too thin and attenuated I think, the bitterness just isnt held up by the malt or enough fruit.  3.6 this time but Ill keep the average at 3.5
Cloudy amber color with small white head. Caramel, apricot, hoppy aroma. Flavor is strong, some caramel and citrus, with a vague alcohol presence.

Bottle #500 pours dark brown with rose & lavendar colored hues, small off-white dishwater like head, with suspended yeasties and light lacing.   Sweet aroma of toffee, light fruits (apple/pear), malts, and a very light hint of alcohol.   Forwardly semi-sweet, light toffee, some citrus (much like a bitter marmalade), malty, with subtle hop hints.   Slightly biscuity and piney as well.   Full body, medium mouthfeel.   Finishes with a bit more of a hop twang, slightly sweet, with minor notes of alcohol.   A good offering, very clean, 10% ABV is well masked.   Could stand to to be a bit thicker with more of a sweet malty profile.   I still prefer Old Ho and Old Boardhead tho.   Thanks goes out to cquiroga for the trade!

Bottle. Deep amber color with a thin off-white head. Gentle toasty aroma, citrus with a bit of honey, not very overpowering. Excellent blending of flavors, the sweet taste of a barleywine with some citrus notes, subtle hop flavoring without the bitterness, and just the right amount of alcohol. Aftertaste leaves the pleasant flavors blended nicely in my mouth long after each sip. Excellent barleywine, rivals the Victory Old Horizontal. Great beer to celebrate the last day of my summer job.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2004 Bottle (9 4 8 4 18).  A deep rust and cherry color with a tan head.   A gloriously rich aroma with cherry, toffee, malts, strongly hopped, and a growing alcohol presence.  Slightly harsh at the first sip with strong vinous elements, but as the beer warms it warmed me and my palate.  A huge barley wine, that left honey, caramel, wood, and dark fruits at the finish. Re-Rate (8 3 8 4 17) (Christmas party 2004 ranked 3/15 (mine) and 5/15 (group)).  A muddy brown color.  Dates, raisins, caramel, wood, and plenty of hops in the flavor.

Bottled. 
Cloudy orange/brown. Dewy, rich aroma with roasted malt. Big malty flavour with fruit and licorice tones.
got this bottle from the Alesmith brewery, thanks tony. pours out a deep brown/ reddish color , very smooth toasty flavor that leaves just enough alcohol  to keep you wanting more. Very nice beer

Bottled: Dark amber coloured. Beige medium sized head. Alcahol, fruit, berries in the aroma. Not enough power. Dominating alcahol. Hops, fruits and alcahol in the flavour. A bit onedimensional. Is bitter in the end. The lips are light burnt by the alcahol.

Thick bubbly head which reduces to a thin foam.  Strong aroma with tons of malts with some caramel and toffee.  Color is a deep ruby/brown and slightly cloudy.  Sweet candy malts with plentiful hops and more caramel.  Finish is bitter.  Thick and coating and warming from the alcohol.  A very good barleywine.  Thanks Eyedrinkale.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005 This bottle brew from JasonG was tasted at DrewLaPalooza 2004.  I was not as impressed with this brew as some of the others were at the event.  It poured a small head of mostly diminished finely sized off-white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body was a transparent brown color and was softly carbonated.  It had a malt hop aroma with a mild vinous note with some caramel.  The mouth feel was initially mild with a lingering caramel malt bite in the finish.  The biting flavor was not one that I preferred at the time.  It also contained hoppy caramel malt notes.

Bottle, after all this time its my first rating of Old Numby.  Pours hazy amber-brown with a small off-white head that lasts and leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is complex, lots of rich roasty maltiness, fruity, spicy with alcohol notes and surprising hoppiness.  Flavor has same characteristics as the aroma, rich and full, teasing the tongue with a changing palette as the brew warmed, lots of dark fruitiness and alcohol warmth to balance the assertive hops.  Full, thick body and a gentle carbontion.  Another winner from Alesmith!

Great aroma, malty sweet with notes of pear, brown sugar, vanilla, tobacco. Very nice. Dark brown amber hazy with thin off-whte head. Thick chewy body with light carbonation. Start very sweet, alcoholic, with red grape, port, oak and vanilla, toffee. Bitter finish, alcohol burn. Sweet nutty finish, very warming. Good stuff.
an amazingly light barleywine, yet still nice an hoppy.  This is a barley wine that blows away everything i expect from a barlywine...  good stuff  :)
Drew-LaPalooza. Translucent brown color, fruity nose (dark fruits), big and smooth malty taste that has a bitter finish. Creamy on the palate. Thanks JasonG.

2003 bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium amber, dense tiny particles, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), moderately hoppy (flowers, grapefruit), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of apricot, orange, honey, toffee, and alcohol. Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Full body, creamy and velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic, lightly astringent.  Fabulous appearance and mouthfeel.  This barley wine is fantastic, and like another reviewer stated this son-of-a-gun is "...beer candy...".  Im glad I bought 12 to put in the cellar.

Drew-LaPalooza beer #7: thanks for bringing this one, JasonG!  Strong fruity hop aroma, this looks thick - leaves thin clear lacing on the sides of my glass.  Flavor is very smooth and creamy - thick but not overly viscous.  Fruits and caramel toffe flavors and then a thick sweet juicy hop.  This is one of those beers that leaves you feeling speachless.

07.23.04  bottle (dated 2/03) thanks to Eyedrinkale.  Clouded, dark amber color with a fluffy, thin head reminiscent of the fading foam on just poured rootbeer.  Sweet and malty aroma, some chocolate, brine, grassy hops.  Flavor is very concentrated and sweet like beer candy.  Velvet mouthfeel.  Retronasal alcohol burn.  Very hoppy for an old beer.   Thank you for sharing this treat, Mike!

Special thanks to Eyedrinkale.   Brown in color and, slightly cloudy with a  tan head. Sherried carmel hop aroma. Hoppy sherried carmel flavors. Malty. The malt  in this lingers nicely. Good sipping beer to be shared with friends.
Excellent.

Special thanks to Eyedrinkale for the 1.5 year old bottle sample, saves me from needing or wanting to break out the bottle I got via trade with Tchrome. Brown, slightly cloudy, tan head. Wonderful sherried carmel hop aroma. Hoppy sharp sherried carmel flavors. The malt in this lingers nicely. This is a real nice sipping beer to be shared with friends.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Pours a light brown with little head. Aroma is earthy hoppy. The flavor was not the tyoical strong hoppy flavor, but rather earthy and toasted grain malt flavored. Alcoholic kick in the background. Flavors are really mellow and kind of bland. Nothing stands out to me to make me buy this again.
Pours a cloudy amber/red. Aromas of sugar/caramel, malt and fruit. Body is lighter than expected, with flavors of sweet malt, caramel, dough and hops come through in the end.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2004 Very nice ruby coloration.  Very malty aroma, with dark fruits, dried fruits, alcohol.  Very smooth, malty, alcohol is very well covered with slight warming.  I dont like Barley wine, but this one is terrific!

pours a reaaaaally deep golden red color.  and very opaque.   nice lasting full dense tan head.  smells like caramel, butter, hops fruits.  reallly nice full smooth palate. tastes roasty chocolate and slight coffee, with a nice buttery hoppy finish.  really a huge barley wine.   very very good.

Mellower than expected, a sweet honeycomb smell mixed with a dust, musty odor. 
Taste smooth , not bitter, murkiness mixed with a brandish taste.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2005 1999 vintage sampled June 2004.  Thanks to Bob (herbjones) for coming through on these vintage AleSmiths.  What a hell of a treat this was.  My friend and I split this.  Hes never tried barleywine, dosent even care that much about beer but he mentioned right away how good this was.  Wonderful mahogany color, with burnished copper tones, light ambers and red swirls.  Aroma has intense english toffee characteristics, old, soily hops, and a big funky yeastiness that blew me away.  Due to the unfiltered/bottle conditioned nature of this beer, the flavors have developed wonderfully these 5 years.  Wonderful caramel and toffee malt flavors, with a now subtle hops profile (soily, earthy, dusty, doughy).  This thing had so much personality and my favorite part was the yeast.  Somehow this thing reminded me of a belgian, I dont know if it was all due to the yeast, or maybe just the interplay of the malt and oxidation, but wow was it unique.  The flavor was as close to perfect as I can imagine.  No harsh tones, low carbonation and a huge, full body.  As much as I respect Old Horizontal, the low filtration on this beer puts this a notch above that one.  This is why I love barleywines. MAN I LOVE THIS BREWERY!!!  10/5/10/5/202003 bottle thanks to EDA!  This one is still obviously young.  This beer takes time to mellow out.  Bitter hops still apparent, but the flavor underneath the up-front hops is as good as it gets, IMHO.  A mix of English and Belgian yeast flavors, light caramel and toffee traces, sticky and just full of flavor.  Ill have to cellar the 2003 another couple of years to see if it truly matches the elegance and craftsmanship of the 1999.  Rerate  2003 bottle sampled in June 2005 at RBSG.  Hmm, the hops still are front and center, but some sticky caramel malt peeks through nicely.  Bitter and lightly astringent on the end.  Seems not nearly as magical and unique as the 1999 and though its still a marvelously executed barleywine, it would have to make a lot of progress as far as yeast apparency (the 2003 has almost none) to really bring it up to the 1999 level.  Or maybe my imagination has just gone running with the 1999.  Fortunately Im well stocked on all vintages so I will be well able to test my theories.  8/5/8/3/152005 vintage  Sampled young on 10/29/05.  Actually prefer this one young to even the 1 or 2 year old 03.  The hops are not nearly as bitter, and while I still think the hops impart too much harshness, its only a minor problem for me.  The malt is very well done, toffee and caramel with an almost candy-sugar like feel.  Orange peel, raisins, grapefruit and a nice earthy, dry malt flavor on the finish.

Old Numbskull is the best Ive found! A big barley wine with a big hop head. The intensity and complexities of this strong ale are so well balanced... there is not much that can be said other than you gotta try this beer. Im lucky enough to live close to AleSmith here in San Diego and Ive just started the growler program. These guys have many fine award winning beers...but I keep my fill of the skull on hand. May the well never run dry!

Vintage 2003. Pours black cherry red with no head. Rich flavorful aroma! Alcohol, malt, caramel, brown sugar, rum-soaked dark fruits, and perhaps even chocolate. WOW! Smooth but alcoholic taste along with more fruit and cocoa. Some lighter hops notes and wood. Silky smooth on the palate. Slight bite during the finish. Damn good barleywine!

Deep, dark, reddish brown color with a small beige head. The aroma contained some alcohol, caramel, sweet apple, and sweet grapefruit. The flavor was very sweet...caramel/toffee, sweet apple, alcohol, grapes, and wet wood. The feel was very thick...soft carbonation, with a semi-wet finish. Very good.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2009 Nice reddish orange color with a smallish beige head. Sweet malt, caramel, and fruit aroma. Nice malt, citrus hops, caramel, and light alcohol flavors. Smooth tingly feel with a fairly dry finish. Nicely balanced. A great barley wine!

Red orange out of the bottle with a lasting off-white head.  Lots of hops in the nose with a malty alcohol foundation.  Sweet syrup, dried fruit with tons of orange rind hop bitterness.  Pleasant alcohol sensations.  Lingering candied orange peel bitterness that lasts a long time on the tongue.  Truely delightful beer.

Thank you jsquire for sharing!  Pours gorgeous medium amber.  Nice lacing.  The aroma is very hoppy and sweet.  The alcohol is quite well hidden in the aroma and flavor.  Very balanced.  This was an excellent barleywine.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 after drinking a bells expedition stout, and realizing that i am done with school for the summer and about to go get more beers from maine and can readily order this from CA- i decided to open my bottle.   sweet smell, pours a dark orange color similar to most barley wines.  thin white head.  smells of alcohol and caramel as well.  hops are more present in the aftertaste, and not so much when first sipped.  i believe this has been aged more than the 3 months i aged it (no way to tell from the bottle).  malty sweet caramel flavor.  nice lingering bitter aftertaste.  a great barley wine- is it as good as bells third coast old ale, no.  is it better than old stock ale?  hell yes.  a great offering.

original rating: 4.6

rerate - 2005 bottle from sean.  I just noticed I had this rated way higher than I should have.  It is a good beer, but in the past few years and many bottles of this consumed, it is no where near what I once thought it was.  Good beer, but not a great beer.
Good slightly sweet, slightly alcoholic aroma.  Body has a good caramel backbone to balance the alcohol, with just the right amount of hops.  This brew ages quite well.

Special thanks to Gusler for sending me this brew.

Pours a cherry wood color that you can't see through but it does allow light through.

Aroma is big with caramel and candied cherries covered in warm toffee.  Alcohol is also very present on the nose.

Flavor is also big with lots of up front sweetness that is soft caramelly candy.  Spicy hops come through also in a fairly big way, this is a really big beer so in reality the hops are big but relative to the rich malts, they take a backseat, but don't back down by any means.  Alcohol warms the finish in a very satisfying way.

Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy, and fairly viscous.

Drinkability, while being hurt by the magnitude of the beer and the alcohol level, is quite good and I'll be enjoying the rest of this bottle with my homemade Arrabiatta sauce on penne noodles.
To quote a local bike shop
"EAT" I'll insert DRINK here as well "CARBS - RIDE YOUR BIKE!"

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2004 Re-rate Nov 25, 04.  Nearly opaque brown pour, minimal head.  Some lace is left around.  Aroma of dry chocolate, molasses, some fruity notes?  Rich feel, nice and thick.  Rich and dark flavors dominate,  dry chocolate again, slight alcohol prescence.  Some sweetness in the flavor, hard to put a finger on though.  Hops throw in some even spice...this is a wonderful range of flavor.  Very nice...cant wait for the barrel aged version.
Nice pour with a modest head, cloudy apparence.  This bottle may have been aged as the hops are beginning to show up in the aftertaste.  overall a potenty barleywine to drink.

Wild flower honey color with a small, but stable ecru head. Just enough lace to make it look interesting. Aromas starts a touch harsh, but warms up nicely. Cookies and cream aromas along with some citric and tropical fruits. Alcohol and plums come out more as it warms, leaving some of the band-aides behind. Floral hops keep it honest. Sweet toasted malt start, covered with honey and kiwis. Hops jump back into the action late and carry the load through the finish. Alcohol kicks in late with a light spicy bite. I'm looking for the malt linger and it does not show itself. Smooth and near oily feel that really dries up in the end. The finish just seems to miss. Otherwise a sensational snifter swig.

Cloudy appearance, a dep amber, a light burgundy, a soft orange playground for the delight I know wait within, and the foam is a sturdy well-retained creamy cap.
Aroma, sharp, ripe fruit, brandy, like boozed-up cherries, sharp, strong, utterly fruity, ...fantastically glorious, so inticing that I need a drink, and wait, here is one, under my nose!
Taste: a hell of a mouthfeel, oh, it fills you, with a full, lush malt, pow, pow, powerful, no baby-steps in the sipping here, no kid-gloves, the ripe fruit, plus intense flavor and full alcohol starts right off, with no relenting. And it continues, ever hotter, like warmed-up cognac, and it nearly stings, it's spicy, kicky, wow, wow, wow...much more than I expect, going into any barleywine. Rich, ripe, tasty fruit continues...I almost run out of things to say, this pleases so generally and so well, ...you've got to be serious about it, with a 750ml of this bomb-a-long-a-ding-dong! Taste gets richer, riper, fruitier...ever-more delicious, if not terrifically strong, too...my last tipple of the night, if that was a question.
Tasty, lip-smackingly delicious...I've got t0 end it there, though I'm still drnking it, but I'm already sure that it ranks among my favorites. Serves as an above-average nightcap....good night, everyone!

UPDATED: APR 30, 2005 A hazy copper color with a thin head and beautiful lacing. Nose is sweet malts, alcohol, candied fruits. Flavour is full and well hopped with a strong, complex malt backbone and a dry finish. The Alesmith craftsmanship really shines in this beer, marvelous stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2004 Cloudy copper with a thin off white quicklky discipating head., The nose is wow hops with lots of citrus. the taste is initially sweet malts and crisp then bam hops with suggar and sweetness. Very good, and easily drinkable.

Thanks to Alcoholist for sharing this.  Pours a cloudy copper with an off-white head.  Rich malty aroma.  Hints of alcohol.  Notes of fruit.  Flavor is rich and rewarding.  Full-bodied, creamy, big and beautiful.  One of the best barley wines available.  Wish AleSmith was more available in the Midwest.

750 ml bottle-pours a cloudy ruby red appearance with nice off white head.  nice sugary, malty and hoppy aroma that was very strong.  smooth palate and silky mouthfeel.  licorice notes on the finish.  This is a top notch barleywine.  thanks to BigBastard for sending it to Whaleman.

Reddish-orange body and fading soapy white head. Piney hop nose with some medium toasty malts underneath. Juniper, pine, and nutty notes in the flavor. Tastes great. Excellent full body. Thanks to BigBastard for this fantastic brew.
Pours a cloudy amber with a thick dissipating head. Big malts and caramel aroma. Sweet flavor followed by a bitter hop finish. Great body. Very nice.

Hazy amber coloured body with a thin but nice tan head. Aroma of many fruits, spicey flavours, alcohol and a strong malt. Medium to Full-bodied; Sweet flavour with fruit and malt the most noticeable, but not harsh in any way. Honey, caramel, oranges and hops are present in the aftertaste. Overall, a great barley wine, simply put: one of the best i've ever had! I got this beer in a trade back in September 2003 from Dave (Rodolito)...thanks again!
apricot nectar color, fruity malt, dried fruit, not overpowering in its sweetness, finish that just won't quit

Fantastic barleywine.  Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, hops, and alcohol.  Thick mouthfeel that makes for a long, lingering finish.  Flavor is as expected, flavorful malt sweetness and floral hops, some alcohol.  Another winner from Alesmith.

(22oz bottle) Many thanks to TChrome for making this available to me. Pours a copper body and a medium white head. Hoppy nose, grapefruit, floral. Balanced with biscuit malt, cascade hops, bubblegum. Tart with marshmellow finish. Very, very good! Thanks again TC!

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2005  2003 green bottle, cheers CapFlu  Hazy orangey amber, very sticky off-white head, fully diminishing into a beautiful film. Aroma displays extremely complex malt profile which Im bound to fall in love with. Potent maple, honey, caramel, cookies, molasses treats. Assertive fruitiness (lots of mango, plenty of peaches, dried bananas, oranges, watermelon, cantaloupe). It smells thick too with notes of bubble gum and brown sugar. Hard to describe overall, but every flavor is well presented and balanced by a subtle hop character and frankly, the best dessert pie never smelled that good. Taste displays more of that bubblegum I adore along with that chemy melon and soft marshmallows. After a few sips, the bitterness gets very pronounced, grapefruity, dry and bitter, a bit too much for me to appreciate in great quantities. Its a little sad though because its my new favorite Alesmith and prefered California barley wine and there was more alcohol than I had hoped for in the taste despite being completely hidden in the aroma. Mouthfeel is top notch though, smooth as hell, velvety, chewy and creamy, medium-bodied and showing a perfect amount of carbonation. Did I say I like the aroma?  Upon resampling, the aroma is still remarkable, but the palate is really too dry and I feel it really takes out fmor the enjoyment. Agressive finish. I lower from 4.4 to 4.2.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2005 Re-rate (16-Jan-05 - 8-3-7-3-14=3.5):  Sweet, round, heavy, dark and pendulous malt aroma with some hoppiness.  Opaque, dark brown with large-bubbled, thin, tan head that recedes to cover.  Heavy malt flavour seems dry and over-attenuated.  Dry and very bitter in the finish.  Quite roasty.  Overbalanced towards the bitterness.  Mild fruitiness and light phenols are overwhelmed by the hops.  Definite strong alcohol flavour and warming.  Very dry, somewhat puckering.  Low carbonation.  Bottle (2004) enjoyed back-to-back with the barrel aged version with asheft, beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, muzzlehatch, Rastacouere and Yowie.


Original rating (3/21/04 - 9-5-8-3-14=3.9): 2003 edition. Citrusy grapefruit (cascade hops?) clean refreshing nose with a biscuity malt aroma and lots of fruity esters - banana, peach, apricot, plum - maybe a bit of bubblegum. Glowing orange colour with decent white head that recedes with good lacing. Big hop flavour with excellent supporting malt base - toasty, biscuity. Hops are citrusy with a vegetal undertone. Nice and complex. Some yeast flavours noted as well. Mouthfeel is incredible - thick, chewy, smooth. Big body. Some sherry sweetness. Just a bit sticky with a dry finish. Hops build and become a bit much by the end of the drink. Seems like an Imperial IPA. Green bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2015 500!  Thanks Eyedrinkale!  Never thought I would hit this mark in a year.  Big thanks to all those who contribute to this site and the many brewers who have dedicated themselves to the craft.  Deep burgundy in color, just a trace of a head.  Big aroma, grapefruit notes clawing their way through a thick veil of syrupy malts.  Initial flavors of toffee and molasses give way to a mixture of tropical fruits and solid pine notes.  Finishes clean and bitter, a flavor that hangs in the mouth long after each swallow.  Well made and delicious, this could be quite spectacular with some age to mellow out the edges.  The 10% is almost imperceptable.  A beer worthy of being #500 and of its Top 50 ranking.  RERATE:  11 years later, finally getting it here in Virginia.  Draft this time.  Having this really brought back quite the flood of memories from the old trading days.  No change to the rating.  Like the Grand Cru, my notes were shockingly similar.  I would only say that it was slighltly smoother than my recollection, with less harsh alcohol notes.  Still a great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2004 (750 ml bottle) AleSmith puts out great beers which results in high expectations, but this one is a little disappointing.  Malty, drier than most, and fairly bitter initially, but the beer has a slightly toasty, dark roasted flavor throughout, especially in the finish and is moderately bitter with a slightly harsh bite on the palate.  Sweet malty nose matches the flavor fairly well.  Reddish mahogany in color and clear, but a dense paste of sediment is on the bottom of the bottle.  Off-white head is small on the pour, disappears quickly and leaves no lacing.Rerated on 08-Nov-04.  This is an aged bottle from 1999, so its 5 years old.  Again, its very malty and only moderately sweet.  But its very smoky in the finish, and that sharp alcohol bite is gone, so aging has really smoothed out this barleywine.  New ratings are based on this session.

Had this one courtesy of radiomgb - THANKS MAN! - after some Brasserie Charlevoix beers he brought over also. I can't say for sure but perhaps as the first beer of the night it would have fared even better - and it was awesome as it was. Potent, smooth, almost nutty, hoppy aroma. Also found malts and caramel and at moments an herbal flair. Sweet but not overly, thick but not syrupy, slightly bitter tinge to finish. All this from a deep orangey ruby amber coloured beer. Wonderful.

Rating #500! A nice treat from Jeremy (jgb9348). Foggy ruby color with a lingering cream colored head. Hoppy aroma, with caramel and some pine as well. Very complex flavor. Some caramel, hops, and malty. A very good beer. My second beer from Alesmith and I am still impressed and wanting more of their beer!!

Orange/amber in colour.  Aroma is very hoppy, with caramel, alcohol and pine.  Flavour was nutty, caramel/toffee, alcohol, quite hoppy and some chocolate.  Finish is hoppy and dry.  Very warming and huge.  Thanks Eyedrinkale.

No vintage date on the bottle, 03? Medium sized light brown head, good retention and lace. Big fruity nose lots of malt and hops that are blended together masterfully. Slightly hazy, amber/copper color. Full body, slick, coating mouthfeel. Complex malt flavors with a balanced hopping rate. Toffeeish, fruity, chewy big beer. Great balance, highly drinkable. Finish is medium sweet with a good hop kick. A well made Barley wine, impressive.

Bottled at a RB gathering in Philly. Thanks to SDBruboy for this bottle. Another fantasic beer from these guys. This had a West Coast hop bite to it with a nice malt finish. Alcohol was hidden pretty well. You could tell it was there however.
I really loved the smell of this one. Big hop and grapefruit aroma. Hops were right up there in the taste, along with citrus, caramel, pine, wet wood, and an alcohol bite. Gotta love that name too!

Impressive Barley Wine from AleSmith.    Extremely complex, yet smooth flavor.   Perfect blend of malts and hop finish.   I believe the bottle I sampled from at RB Philly Gathering was 2002 vintage.   Hands down the best bottle of beer with a foil top I ever had.

A bit hoppy--cherries, vanilla, apples, pears in nose.  Super sweet, very balanced, alcohol only in aftertaste.  Lower carbonation made this silky instead of sticky.  Mmm mmm good.  Had at RB Philly gathering February 2004.
Hazy copper color with an off white head, and some lacing.  Somewhat hoppy, fruity, cherry aroma.  Malty taste of caramel, hoppy, fruit and alcohol, with a full and even creamy mouthfeel.

First of all: Thanks DaSilky for this beauty. Nice hazy orange color iwht a little foamy head. Hoppy but also sweet banana taste with some apricot tones. Flowery and grassy nose. Round and very thick with a little bite of hops but it*s kind of flat.

Hoppy, spicy, syrupy nose; reddish-brown color; low frothy head. Big fruity malt body (apricots) witha  lingery high resolution bitterness. Great great balance. Thick, but flatish. At least there is an alcohol kick here.

The first thing I noticed about this beer was the hops bursting from the bottle the second the cap was removed. This isn't entirely rare, but slightly unusual for barley wines. There are definitely some strong hop influences in the flavor as well, backed up with a great mouthfeel and very solid dark malty hues, although the beer never really lends itself to the sweeter side of things, always keeping that hoppiness at the forefront. I noticed some resiney pine as well, perhaps a bit of grassiness too. Nothing too complex I felt, actually bears a great deal of resemblence to the Stone Guardian. Very tasty, although I may have been a tad bit fooled if someone were to tell me this were an Imperial IPA.

aroma is of malt, pine, and alcohol. pours a burnt orange with a light tan head.  flavor is sweet and smooth with fruity malty notes.  also has kind of a woody flavor to it.  alcohol is warming. has decent lacing. this is pretty good and if I can ever get it again I will.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2004 1/29/04 I was stoked to try my first west coast barleywine.  Only thing is, it wasnt completely fresh. Poured a cloudy orange-brown color with no head.  Smelled a bit like oranges and cloves.  Tasted kinda like orange liquer.  The palate was decent expect on the roof of my mouth where it kind of felt like a runny egg.  Try not to take this rating to serious, the beer was still pretty good for being opened and re-sealed 4 days ago.  Ive just been a little too "under the weather" to drink it.  This all gives me more incentive to re-rate it.

12/26/04 Finally got a chance to re-rate a fresh one thanks to Santa.  Much better.  Flavors are prunes, dates, and a subtle carmel.  Great carbination, so smooth.  Hides the alcohol well.

Amber brown body, little to no head or lace.  Aroma is perfume hops with some citrus and grape notes and a nice sweet malt backbone.  Flavor is malt sweetness balanced by some citrusy and lightly evergreen bites, Also some lighter fruit flavors pear,white grape.  Big heavy mouthfeel finishing with a nice fading hop flavor and bitterness.  I liked it.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2005 Beautiful crimson brown color. Small, but tight white head. Aroma is malty with caramel and raisin notes. Smooth and malty with hints of caramel and some toasty notes. Nice dry hoppy finish, to balance things out. Everything a barleywine should be. Big thanks to Jokes for sending this one out.  

Re Rate 2/19/05: Bright redish brown with a thin white head. Malty, toasty aroma with hints of cherry and molasses. Flavor is much more hoppy than I remember. Flavor is almost dominated by piney hops, some juniper notes as well. Alright, but nothing compared to my first sample.

Big up front sweet malt aroma, just a touch of hops. Sweet earthy malts, very nice hop balance, some lingering bitterness. Rich and full body, some alcohol coming through. Solid all around. Big thanks to frielock for sharing such a rarity in these parts with me.

Amber color, cream colored head that fades. Huge hop aroma with malt and alcohol. Big malt sweetness followed by hop bitterness with alcohol. Med body that is thined down some by the alcohol. some oxidation but not too high. The oxidation did distract some from the overall flavor. Will need to try again with out the oxidation. Overall a fairly good american barley wine.
Solid malt aroma with good hops. Flavor of malt and hops predominate with a slightly bitter finish. One I will keep and age for awhile!

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2004 750 ml. green champagne bottle. Capped, but not corked. 2000 batch. Acquired thru a trade with Eyedrinkale. No freshness date seen or noticed. Poured out a cloudy, orangish - caramel colored beer. It had a thin head, but it left more than a decent lacing around the edges of my tulip glass. I've been waiting a long time to try this beer, so let's begin. Aromas are of caramel, slightly smoky malts, and candi sugar. Sweet aromas overpower the hops, which struggle to maintain a presence in all the malts.
Slight aromas of alcohol, way off in the background. Tastes are incredible. Chewy caramel, roasted oatmeal, slight fruitiness, and strong English malts. I'll wager this beer is made with English grains. Maybe some Marris Otter or something along those lines.
Thick, viscous mouthfeel, but not syrupy. Not cloying at all.
More along the lines of a well aged Samichlaus. Finishes dry, and with a biscuit taste as well. An incredible take on the style of beer.
Much more an English Barleywine than an American version.

Finally glad to rate an AleSmith. Dark red and heavy, great fruity aroma. Almost every aspect of this beer is great. Maybe a tad too much on the ABV. I keep enjoying more and more types of theses beers. Each one keeps getting better and better as this one.

Got it at the brewery. Pours with a very typical bottle conditioned head. Lots of frothy bubbles. Lots of yeast and other sediment. I think this was a year or more old. Light syrupy amber, surprisingly trasluscent. Smells of alcohol, ripe prunes, papaya and maybe even starfruit. Very palatable. Even dangerously drinkable. The hops at this point do not attack the front but instead spread there wonder over the back of the tongue and lie there long after the glass is empty. As it warms, a honey-like sweetness becomes apparet and the alcohol begins to bounce around in your brain like a candy-kid at a rave. Never do the flavors become cloying. This ale is menacingly enjoyable from start to finish and the only negative to speak of is that I have only one bottle. Woe is me!
UPDATED: JAN 31, 2004 Nice red color with an almost white head. Very complex sweet fruity aromas. Molasses and malt surround the beautiful hop taste. Another Alesmith winner !

1/4/04.  Poured out of 750 mL bottle, bought at A&J Liquor in Covina, CA 11/28/03.  2000 Vintage.  My 100th rating, and I made it a special one.  Dark, dark amber color-- slightly opaque.  Small, rocky head that lingers very thin with clumpy lacing.  Unbelieveable nose-- fruit, caramel, and mellowing malts with some slight mustiness blend deliciously with the apparent alcohol complement and a light corkiness.  Medium-dark caramel malts with hint of burnt flavor.  Some pale sweetness and some muted, darkly bitter, leathery hops.  Flavor expands smoothly and impressively.  Finish just explodes into a tremendous blossom, drying with bitterness and a very long, delicate berry sweetness.  Medium-full body with man different flavors swirling and dancing on the palate, all taking the spotlight at different moments.  Sticky on the lips.  Just want to savor it and let it sit on the mouth-- but if you let it sit too long it almost overwhelms you.  Could definitely still age a bit longer and improve, but I'd like to have the alcohol pulled back a bit, and I don't know if that'd happen.  Also, bitterness of hops is a little too prevalent/prominent, which is funny, because I didn't think the same thing about the newly-bottle '03 version.  Also, it's odd, but the lacing became tremendous on my second pour from the bottle.  One of my favorite beers around.

Mahogany pour with a large off white creamy head and thick lacing.  Very nice aromas of chocolate, grape wine, nice citrus hops, some yeast and alcohol.  Malt flavors start us going here. Next come a myriad of hops, citrus fruits, small chocolate and a touch of alcohol. Full bodied with a thick palate. Finishes out with a hoppy alcohol. Very nice barley wine.

Ruby/tawny color with nice sticky head and light lacing. The aroma is nicely malty with a blanced hoppyness. Delicious balance! Flavor is nicely sweet with some honey and malt finishes and some hops to balance. Awesome barleywine balance, straight forward yummy.

Very aromatic with glorious hop richness.  Copper red with large tan head and good lacing.  Flavor was smooth and balanced.  This has to be the best barley wine I have ever tried!  Exceptional in every way.
Clear bright ruby red color with a small white head, ok lacing.  Surprisingly subdueded aroma and taste.  A slight lemon scent.  A quality brew.

Awesome pungent piney hop aroma. Reminded me of arrogant bastard but sweeter. Deep copper color. Taste is rich and complex with sweet malt typical of barley wines with a very healthy dose of hops, which makes this beer so damn good.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2005 This beer when held up to the light is a hazy copper-orange color, otherwise it is a fairly drab amber color.  It is topped by a fairly dense tan head.  The aroma at first is all hops; grapefruit & flower nectar.  As I smell more the malt comes out in the aroma.  The malt aroma helps to thicken the aroma of the hops in this beer.  The taste is surprising in its restraint from bitterness.  The hop flavor is here in full force though  The body of this beer is like a beefy giant.  I find myself enjoying this beer quite a bit.  The interplay of the malt and hop is quite well done.  The predominant taste is that of a hoppy nectar, there is a solid malt character & the bitterness is fairly subtle for an over hopped big beer (which I really like here).  There seems to be some light oxidation notes here (perhaps a hint of sherry), which helps to further the complexity.  Quite enjoyable and I have a full 750 to savor this evening.

Big malt and hopswith subtle fruitiness and alcohol in the aroma.  Beautiful red-amber in color with a persistent off-white head.  Flavor is sweet malt at first, followed by spicy, grassy hops, then finishes with huge hop bitterness.  The commercial description is pretty dead on. Full bodied, slighty warming.  Great American-style barleywine, wonderfully balanced.

Thanks BierBauch.  Impressive example of the sytle. The beer is amber in color and slightly hazy.  The aroma hits you with caramel and hops.  The first sip is characterized by alcohol with a slight vanilla tone  A bitter residual tone is left on the back of the palate.  Overall hints of vanilla, nutmeg and some caramel.  Very good...sort of lesser hopped Bigfoot.

On tap.  Dark hue with almost no head.  A very in your face flavor with an overbearing smokiness to it. There were some caramel and fruity notes also but the roasted malt/smoky flavor overwhelmed this one.  My least favorite of the Alesmith releases to date.

Poured a dark orange red color, somewhat murky with a medium tan head.  Aroma is very malty with nice hop bitterness as well.  Also detect some alcohol and fruits.  The hop bitterness is noticable as soon as you take a sip.  Next is a wonderful caramel malt mixed with spicy notes.  Finish is sticky and bitter.  A great brew.

Nice orange reddish hue with lasting off-white head and good lace. The aroma of this beer is wonderful, get the piney and grapefruit character of an IPA with the malty, sweet fruity and spicy character of an Belgium strong ale. Additional grain and yeast esters as well on the nose. The taste is almost shocking in it's sublime attack on the palate. First, you get a smash of piney hops then followed closely by a deep malty and spicy, almost Scottish ale like, complex tones. Extreme balance with both ends of the taste spectrum carefully measured against each other. A nice fruity component adds to the rich and lush flavors. Medium to full-bodied with a great mouthfeel, this barley wine (if you can call it such) rocks! The lingering grapefruit twang is almost too much and is my only major knock against this brew. Unique within the genre, this is a must try for all Ratebeerians. An Imperial IPA???

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Cascade hops and pine and scotch in the aroma.  Smalles like Arrogant Bastard!  Just a little bit murky, deep amber hue.  Very strong and musty up front, with caramel, pine and scotch flavors through the finish.  A little bland on the tongue, novacaine-like feeling, but nice.

This is a great Barley Wine if thats what they want to call it, because I feel its more of a mix of styles(IPA).  Sweet, malty, hoppy, and fruity flavors.  Finishes dry, clean, and smooth.  Recommended.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2004 Surprisingly hoppy aroma for a Barley Wine style. Slightly hazy and deep amber like the color of Anchor Liberty. Has a nice big head and laces well. Wonderful peach or apricot flavors with big hops that are bittering. Although not a typical Barley Wine style, this is one fantastic brew. Doesn't have the sweet malt of a Barley but more like an Imperial IPA. Alcohol is masked completely. Not a fan of Barley Wine but this was right up my alley!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
2002 Vintage - Big 750ml dark green bottle with a silver foil top- pours out to a magnificent deep russet brown color; great color, very leathery and deep with a thick light tannish head thats fluffy and lays down to a skim always present, mostly lasting through consumption and fades some to a thin ring, lace in thin sheets at first but then becoming spots later.

Smell is all heft! Lots of thick malts, rich, caramel-tastic, darkly sweet and deep, some fruitly darkenedness with a heft of hops as well with piney resin thats highly floral and sweet. Nice alcoholic warmth much like a brandy over the top in the aroma as well. Yum! Aroma-rific!

Taste is mellowing smooth and warm with a good amount of deep and thick malts, a bit chewy and lightly roasty sweet, good caramel and fainted earthyness, some darker fruits show through with plum and fig, some mango, all showing the true front of a barleywine; malty! Hops then come in with a super fine and resiny bitterness thats quite easy to handle and has some light pineyness and deep floral notes. Seemed to lose some complexity as it warmed, it really mellowed out. The mellowness made it much more easy to drink, but the enjoyment level dropped some though as far as the flavor punch. 

Solid soothing medium body feel with a smooth creamy lingering chewy finish with some warmth hidden well but acceptable in its presense of what is traceable amounts mostly coming through the nose. A nice mellow BW, some longer lasting body and flavor and this would stay year round in my fridge, not that it wouldn't now, I can't really get it here in MN, otherwise if it was I would.

A red body is topped by a medium thick off-white foamy head wit good lacing left on the glass.  The aroma is sweet, malty and full of caramel notes with a fruitiness lingering in the background.  The flsvor is sweet and malty with a good hoppiness and notes of caramel and fruit.  A slight hint of alcohol is also noticed.  the finish is sweet yet bitter and hoppy.  Medium to full bodied and tingly on the tongue.

Rating #215.. So my Saturday beer tasting culminated with Old Numbskull, and thanks to Bigbadbear63 for sending me the Smiths. 
The Numbskull consistently poured a deep and robust mahogany colored body with little to know head, although it did leave behind a slight ring of lacing. 
I think an accurate description of this beers aroma and flavor is, a syrupy caramelized brown sugar and grapefruit. This beer has serious Grapefruit zestyness, nice hefty malt additions but its really just Enormous Hops that give this Barley Wine a smooth dry finish. Notes of plums, figs, and pares are also additions that bring depth to this beer.
 I must admit that I was impressed by the Numbskull but it was very similar to the Ale Smith IPA; I wonder if they accidentally bottled the Barley Wine in the IPA bottle, yeah probably not, but the similarities are remarkable.

Medium red brown color. Small frothy white head. Aroma is bready, malty and sweet. Touches of fruit and some mustiness. A full-bodied barley wine. Malts are nutty, bready, fruity and slightly sweet. Hops are grapefruity and slightly bitter. The malts are very smooth and creamy. There are a lot of complex flavors going on in this beer. Nicely balanced and very smooth. The malts really shine in this English style barley wine. Hides the 10% alcohol very well. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Dark amber and murky with a frothy tan head. Big malty hoppy aroma. Fruity and alcoholic. Flavor is awesome! Hop bitterness bites the cheeks and the sweet fruity malts wallop the tongue. Creamy/syrupy body with a nice smooth finish. The flavors stick to you. Yum-yum.

Very nice amber color,Small head that had a small amount of staying power,Fruity aroma sort of sweet,raisins and malt with a hint of alcohol and a slight wine like character IMO.The flavor was malty sweet and definately fruity with a nice amount of alcohol but not enough to make it hard to drink,theres almost more flavors here then i can identify they change so quick it would take 2 bottles for me to pick them all out.I confess i have a slow pallate.The after taste was malty sweet and kind of lingering on that with a heavy feel in the mouth.The alcohol is nicely done and fairly well balanced .This is a fantastic brew and i have to thanks Raindog for providing me with this one.

Clear amber-brown with a frothy head. Wonderful aroma, with notes of black licorice, raisin, dates and fruity alcohol. Chewy, thick, smooth and warming on the tongue and throat. Malts were thick, chalky and cookie-sweet. Substantial, fresh-baked bread aromas exuded, which drifted nicely into the aftertaste. Some yeasty notes, too. Hops kept up wonderfully and balanced everything out.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2005 rerate----  Pours clear deep amber/reddish hue with a light tan head with wonderful lacing .  MMMMM.....the aroma is amazing.  Aromas of caramel, a little toffee, roasted nuts and  a hint of dates and raisins.  Thick mouthfeel with a lingering finish, but in a good way.   Flavors of butterscotch,  some brown sugar, a hint of oakiness, a little tobbacco in the finish and a little heat from the alcohol, not overwhelming, just warming.   Much better than I remember it.  old rating---This is a sipping beer that is more carbonated thatn others.  This also adds a thickness to the brew.  It is very fruity and fresh, and a little dry on the palate 6/4/7/3/15---3.5

split a bottle with andrew196 on my recent journey back to texas.  i have this beer halfway in between foghorn and hog heaven.  i think 196's problems with it stem from the bars we closed down before our tasting.  great beer, some time in the cellar could make it even better.

Bottle.  I liked this better than my braugh.  Deep amber appearance, respectable head.  Big flavor all-around: nice citric notes that somehow transition into more sweet fruits (peaches, nectarines) in the finish.  Malts become apparent, especially as it warms.  A bit sour in places but overall a very respectable beer.

An excellent barleywine indeed, but not worthy of being in the top 1% of beers on this website.  Lots of hoppiness in the nose, reminiscent of Avery Hog Heaven in that aspect.  Flavor was full and rich, fruity malts with lots of alcohol.  Finish was dry, a bit off too, couldnt really pin point what went wrong.  The bottle I had could have used some aging.  Still, an excellent beer.....Im just a bit critical because of this beer's status on the site.

Bottle: 2000 vintage. You could smell the age. Malt dominated. Rich carmel//molasses. Hazy amber color. Burnt carmel flavor. Finish was creamy, but was balanced by the strength. Very tasty. Thanks JCalabre
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 3, 2004 This beer is beautiful.  Nice lace with small retaining head.  Creamy, oily mouthfeel.  Not as sweet as expected which is nice.  Pretty bitter in the finish but very well balanced.  Very smooth.  I'll have to try this against Victory Old Horizontal.  Awesome.  Rereat 070304:  Growler fill.  Very creamy and smooth.  Compared to one like Barefoot, the Old Numbskull is smoother and less hoppy.  Very spicy and much more refined.  Excellent.

I had the pleasure of trying two vintages in one night! 2000: Nose is all malt and oak.  Taste is all malty and fruity. Subtle velvety mouthfeel. Aftertaste of roasted nuts. 1999: Lots more yeasties. Flavors are very similar, however it appeared that this bottle was mildy "corked," which I learned means that the cork has given a slight carboard taste to the finish. Regardless, great beer.

2000 - 3 years is a long time for a "beer". This bottle was just purchased at a store down the street. I can't imagine a store holding a beer that long. As I poured this beer into the glass, I see dark amber goodness with a white thin head. Not much in the nose..first drink seems somewhat two dimesional, hop bitterness and alcohol. The silky mouthfeel and warmth let you know this beer is special. After the glass warms up out come the malt intensity,fruity flavors and aroma. This beer continiously evolves as you enjoy it. What a beer! Time for the second glass, good night!

Stay away if you don't want to get kicked in the ass.  Beer pours light brown with huge head that sits ther and refusses to go away.  Aroma is massive hops and malt.  This is NOT a beer for the masses.  Massive initial hop assault with significant malt sweetness.  HUGE BEER.  AWESOME.

Dark red brown. . . Great hop/plant aroma. . . Velvety palate with a slight tingle.  Some very interesting spice - so smooth and creamy, light - not that harsh bitter in-your-face finish so many big BW are hitting us with. . . Goregous finish, simply amazing, Trap many thanks.

Should have let this one age a bit longer, but I couldn't wait.  Nice maltiness and bitterness balance out the alcohol flavor.  All sorts of aromas, citrussy and ehtanol. Great beers, great brewery, and Pete the owner is a great guy!

Bright reddish appearance, thick head of tan foam. Citric floral aroma, malt prevalent, similarities to Arrogant Bastard. Alcohol jumps out on the first sip, mellowing out with crystal malts, shortbread and vanilla before a heavily citric finish. This also shows some signs of gin like botanicals although to lesser extent than in Stumblin Monk.

Excellent barleywine!  Big grapefruity/citrusy hops and pear/apricotty nose.  Thick and chewy caramel malts with some smoky, bacony notes that give way to sweet sugary apple and some alcohol burn.  Hops is evident and stronger as the glass warms, mixing with the alcohol for a quick and dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2005 Seriously citric hoppy, bitter nose, sweet with vanilla and hazel nut notes, alcohol. Cloudy, reddish brew. Flavor is mostly bitter, hop dominated, a dry mix of what seem to me Saaz and Cascades, over a powerfully sweet backbone with caramel, vanilla. Some citrus; very dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2006 2003 sampled on 5/19/2004: Pours a rich dark copper brown with a thick light tan head. Aroma of grapes, sweet caramel and nice hop balance.  The hops are much more prevalent in this newer version than in the aged ones, but it is still well balanced.  A great barleywine, and yet another great Alesmith beer.

1999 sampled on 12/23/2003: Again, more difficulty opening the bottle, but this time it was the cork that broke off into little pieces that fell into the beer.  Aroma is still full of toffee and caramel malt, but is showing more age.  Good sweetness and dark fruit complexity within, but this is probably past its prime, although it has held up very well.

2000 sampled on 7/2/2003: After the difficulty of opening the bottle, the beer poured an amber orange color with a thin white head.  Aroma of freshly baked chocolate chip cookies and grapes.  Sweet complex body with good malty sweetness, well-balanced English-hop bitterness, and a satisfying, dry, filling finish with little noticeable alcohol.  Great smooth flavor and balance.  Aged tremendously well.  I love this brewery!

2003.  A deep caramel color with little head.  A wonderfully hoppy aroma.  Citrus, pine, and strawberry with a hint of alcohol.  Caramel and whisky smoked malt begin a flavor profile that finishes with warming alcohol and plenty of hoppy bitterness.  Smooth and almost creamy.  Maybe not the most typical American barleywine, but still very nice.

At this point I really think AleSmith can do no wrong.  I love thier offerings, the only problem being that they are brewed so sparsely; or maybe that is party why I love them.  CaptainCougar and I had a hell of a time removing the pseudo-plastic/waxy top.  And then the cork broke in two.  Slightly dark amber with a thin head initially.  Sweet, hoppy nose and definitely an English barleywine.  Caramel, smoke, with a whispy, silky mouthfeel.
2000, bottle.  Big malty and sweet aroma.  Brownish / orange in color.  Fruity and apricot like taste upi front with smooth finish.  Very good, not a hoppy barley wine.  More english that american.

2003 on tap at OBriens. A clear amber with a reddish tinge. Thick beige head. Thick aroma full of hops and malt (dominated by hops). Sweet, caramel malty flavor with a hoppy sweet aftertaste. Hops are pretty strong at this point. Full mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Rich creamy finish. This will be great once it ages a bit more.

This was a very nice Barley Wine, much better than that of the name of the Stone brand, but who is counting. A very deep assault of hops that continues throuout the entire brew, and for the most part never finises, it just follows a curvalinear line. Hints of hoppy acidic malt, but this would be a treasure if it were aged, did you here me, a fucking treasure.

2002-2003 Vintage:  The only thing i found dissapointing about this beer was that i got very little aroma from it. the flavor was full of sweet maltiness and a few fruity esters.  the body was surprisingly light for the style but that helped.  i could drink this stuff all night...it would just be a short night since the alcohol definitely makes itself felt.  there is a slight warming in the mouth and the belly from the alcohol.  the body is a clear and dark ruby with a tan head that dissipates very fast due to the alcohol content.  another great offering from alesmith.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2006 2006 bottle. Head is initially small, frothy/fizzy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy dark amber, unfiltered. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, caramel), lightly to moderately hoppy (resin, grapefruit), with notes of alcohol, candied fruit, sherry. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, soft/flat carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Not as badly oxidized as it sometimes is, but overall pretty ordinary and unexciting.

2000:  First taste of this barleywine came across as bitter with hints of butterscotch.  But as this barleywine warmed, the flavors really became much more apparent.  Creamy caramel, a little bit of peat/smoke, and more butterscotch.  Rich with a good balance of malt and hops.  Recommended.

2000. Quickly sticks me with rounded bitterness and blended well with malt flavors. A sweet and sour complex that might join well with Chinese food. Citric hop character, medium creamy and soft feel/body, high roasty tones, some softened tannic notes, from glass to glass this beer continues to punish.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2006 2000: It was the night of the Grand Masquerade...A glorious, festive aura hung about the ballroom all evening as Epicureans from all around exhibited exquisite costumes and perfumes...Wise cranberries sallied forth with a cherry mask...Monarch grapes were scantily veiled by luscious caramel...Prim peaches paraded as proud rosemary leaves...And later on in the soirée, the gates of the hall were opened and a smell of freshly mowed lawn penetrated the creamy atmosphere, a gesture for which many were grateful...The only smudge on this otherwise very luxurious celebration was that the alcohol arrived unmasked and, moreover, crowded some of the other participants with its impolite and loud blabber...A few 2003 and 2004 bottles recently tasted proved to be a bit green hoppy but all wondrous complexities remain...This needs to age a bit before reaching full potential...
The 2000 was as smooth and lovely as a Barleywine gets.  Through some patient aging, I found this to be easily the finest Barleywine that I have ever tasted.  Cant wait to open my second bottle.
Fruity aroma, a cloudly brownish, orange in appearance.  Taste very malty sweet to me.  I only notice the hops on the finish.  Its not my favorite Barleywine, but its certainly a good one.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2005 6/24/02: The candy sweet injection of molassis penetrated my olfactory glands and collided with the dirty-blood glow that reflected in my eyes..  Cream infused cream growing creamier and creamier as temperatures rise..  This was once my all-time favorite beer..Re-Rate 9/17/02: it started cold and inferior..the scare of changed perceptions..but as temperatures rose..and flavors awakened..The memories came alive..not as colorful as before..but still quite vivid with increased hoppy awareness

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2004  7/11/02  2000 Vintage: I LIKE IT, I LOVE IT, I WANT SOME MORE OF IT !!!   A BIG beautiful beer in a big beautiful bottle. I'll be back for more!   
10/23/02  2000 Vintage: Second verse, same as the first! Hazy peach/amber color with a thin creamy head. Sweet, thick, rich with a light bitterness. Nice balance of malt and  hops. Fantastic barley wine. Thanks Peter.
7/30/03 2003 Vintage: Pours a deep mahogany color in my Duvel glass. Head is thick and tan. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Flavor starts malty and sweet and transitions to a light bitterness balanced so very well by the malt. Aftertaste is long and mouth watering. Oh so smooth on the palate.You can feel the alcohol warmth in your face.

The aroma is delightful. Very lambic-like. Malty, citrusy, woodsy and lightly spicey.
This hazy amber brew has a small, off-white, creamy head with good lacing. The head is fully lasting.
Wow, what a great tasting barleywine.
Lightly sweet and moderately malty up front. Almost perfectly balanced by the dry, fruity bitterness on the backside. Warm alcohol feel in the mouth, throat and stomache. Its really more of a feeling than a flavor. I love it. Woodsy (American White Oak?) flavor throughout. Hints of honey, caramel and fuzzy fruits as well. Full-bodied. Lively carbonation and a slightly creamy/slightly alcoholic mouthfeel. A medium length, lightly bitter, lightly pungent and mostly dry finish. Lingering flavors of honey and alcohol on the palate at the very end of the delightful finish. This is, without a doubt, the most unique barleywine I have ever tasted. In the aroma and the flavor, this barleywine resembles an excellent, hopped lambic with a ridiculously high alcohol content. I love lambics, I love barleywines, I love this beer. A very very high score for this masterpiece. Thanks go out to herbjones for this great beer.

From the same tasting as aracauna... The aroma is pleasingly complex.  It pours up nicely, with a rich light ruby body capped by a foamy off-white head that disappears with reluctance.  The flavor is also complex, with a nice malt base, with a good dose of hops on top.  As it warms, the alcohol and hops intrude more on ones senses.  It sits nicely in the mouth.  Overall, an extremely good beer when youre in the mood for something complex.

This is for the 2000 Numbskull tasted on 10-25-02.

Nice medium maltiness. Starts off a bit bland, but the bitterness slowly picks up as does the alcohol. Ends up really good. Body is dark reddish amber with an off-white head. Theres some lemon zest in the aroma. I think its a compbination of the alcohol, malt and yeast.
another CLASSIC from SKIP and TODD the brewers at Alesmith

An amazingly accessible barley wine.  Its not cloyingly sweet, as Ive come to expect a barley wine to be.  Theres plenty of alcohol and malt in the flavor, but neither drown out the flavor of the hops.  Very impressive flavor -- pleasant, balanced, and just plain good.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 2000 Edition:  Complex aroma that has bits of maple syrup and citrus fruits.  Its hazy orange/brown color looks just as good as the gold painted bottle.  The head is made of the smallest bubbles that I've seen in a while and they make some of the best lacing that I've ever seen.  The palate deserves a 6, due to a unique creaminess that it has.  The taste is restrained, perfectly balanced, and is capable of making you want to drink this gem too fast.  Gusler, you are The Man and a million thanks to you!

2000 bottling. Aroma is pleasant but demure.  There is some caramel-dipped apple, a tinge of alcohol and a slight floweriness.  Deep red-orange hue with apparent effervescence, but head fades quickly to a slight ring.  Flavor profile is mellow for a West Coast barleywine.
