Some laid-back caramel, a bit of citrus (both flavor and feel), spices, and towards the finish, the noble hops spicy bitterness becomes much more distinct.  Palate is largely dry.  Aftertaste has both malt and hop balance along with a bit of alcohol, more felt than tasted.  This would be great to lay down for another year and a half or so, I have a feeling it would improve.  This is most certainly a wonderful beer.  Warming.
Dark orange color, floating chunks.  Malty, long bitter finish.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2003 update 8 May 2003: Trying the 1999 vintage, it's a hazy burnt orange color w/ a small head & a nise nose of green apples. Velvety on the tongue & sweet, it's a delite.
Now the downside: the cork was sealed w/ some sort of shrink-wrapped rubber that had adhered to the bottle via concrete. What a pain in the ass to open!

2000 vintage: reddish brown in color, malty, w/ a slightly sweet taste & a dry finish. I taste a little vanilla/orange flavor. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2003 2000 bottling. Extremely smooth, fitting style. Quite sweet and I'm not finding the separation of flavors I might like...well, there's sweet + alcohol in the nose, then sweet + alcohol in the taste (OK, serious vanilla as well). Expertly crafted, just so strong and sweet I can't really get into it (but lord knows it can get into me!) OK, upon warming, and *please* let it do so, I'm getting real nice hop bitterness plus pepper at the very tip of the tongue, pulling through at the finish that helps resolve the incredible sweetness.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: I thought the old foghorn was one of the best barley wines I had until I had this one. Sweety finish slightly fruity with a nice malty touch to it! Try it!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 (2003 750ml bottle 2-5-05) Cloudy copper body with off-white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, toffee, caramel, grapefruit/earthy.  Taste is moderately sweet, toffee, grapefruit, caramel.  Moderately full body with a fairly clean finish.  (8/4/8/4/16).  (RBSG02) Deep rich alcohol malty aroma.  Beautiful unfiltered orange.  Hoppy/malty balance so wonderfully balanced for a barleywine -- Im tongue-tied (pen tied?).  Delicious, great aftertaste of bitter with hint of alcohol.  (9/4/9/5/18).
Yes its very smooth, but I think that it is a bit overdone. Hmm so much hype about this one (top 10) .Oh well...

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2003 Re-rate 6-20-2003. This review is for the 1999 vintage of Numbskull. This beeer is damn near perfection. Easily drinkable full of cherry and vanilla notes. Good hopping still after all these years. The beer is perfect the only thing holding me back from a 5 is the freaking cork breaking off and crumbling in one of the bottles.2000 edtion, poured a copper color with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is a very mellow malty/ caramel. I have to admit that I'm not a barleywine lover, but this is extraordinary! Sweet malty taste that is smooth and creamy. This is one of the best beers I have ever had. I tried Old Foghorn years ago and was determined not to try this style again but AleSmith is something I cant pass up. I'm gonna have to go and try some more barleywines now and see if I've been missing something.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2003 Let's get this bad boy over the hump.2000 vint.Pours like liquid silk.Beautiful ruby red color.Milky,lacey,light tan head.Unique fruit aromas and SWEET malt aromas.Mellowed to a ridiculous state.Lush,creamy,smooth,palate with a subltle hop presence.IMO alcohol was never present.A KEEPER.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2005 2005: Muddled, entirely alcoholic, dirtily yeasty, and brashly hoppy. My how things have changed. 2000 Vintage:<p/>   The cork popped with absolutely no authority, which had me worried.  My worries abruptly ended as I witnessed loads of tiny bubbles hitting the copper liquid with such buoyancy.  The dense and sticky bubbles were a sheer delight to view.  The aroma is packed with hops (citric), alcohol, leather, brown sugar, oranges, and pineapples.  The palate is just another excellent demonstration of this beers utmost quality.  It exhibits characteristics of a fine English barleywine with its lush malt profile.  But the substantial hop bitterness lets you know it is indeed an American barleywine at its finest.  Creamy, perfect CO2 level, sticky, slightly vinous, and semi-dry are just a few to name.  Juicy dark raisins, as if picked this morning, were exhibited, as were oranges, brown sugar, discerning chocolate richness, spruce/pine, and a delectable maple syrup sweetness. A noticeable, yet very tolerable alcohol warmth slides down the throat with ease.  I see this aging well for another three to four years.  Perhaps longer?  If this isnt the definition of a desert/nightcap beer, what is?
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 20, 2003 Cloudy red copper with a beautiful creamy head and lace. Awesome nose of malts,fruits,alcohol and Bit O' Honey. Medium to thick bodied, very smooth with a malt profile with caresses of honey that is to die for. Alcohol and wonderfully bitter hopping take over but the malt rides it through to the end to provide the balance. Awesome, awesome barelywine. If you love barelywines, you will love this. I definitley need about 6 of these to put away.  Thank you Gusler, this was definitley a "hoot"!
Red-brown. Relatively light bodied and drinkable for a barley wine, big aromatic hop bitterness. A beer to love in a beautiful bottle!

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2004 As the beer extravasates from the 750ML green bottle, into my Stone Double Bastard glass, as one big old beer needs to be in a big old bad assed glass, and none seems more fitting! The color a good-looking translucent deep burnished copper with a statuesque and spumescent light tan head that ever so slowly dissolves leaving a thick and somewhat chunky coating of lace upon the glass. Nose is sweet malt, hints of fusel alcohol, hints of cotton candy, fresh and clean to the senses, with the start ambrosial and thickly malted with a moderate to almost full feel to the palate at the top. Finish is craggy in its acidity, the hops unrelenting in their spiciness, the aftertaste somewhat alcohol bitter, droughty and long lasting and a definite belly warming sensation, and a beer Ive always found appealing, and one that gets better over time.

Note: After decanting the beer does have a definite obfuscated burnished copper appearance, got to love all that Gunk coating the bottom of the bottle!
notably good barley wine, with a large, chewy malt palate balanced by a dry finish showing English hops.
